editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: LƲSƲS POETICƲS LATINO-Anglicanus, in usum Scholarum.

OR The more eminent sayings of the Latin Poets Collected; and for the service of Youth in that Ancient exercise, commonly called Capping of Verses, Alphabetically digested; and for the greater benefit of young beginners in the Latin Tongue, rendred into English.
By John Langston Teacher of a private Grammar-School near Spittle-fields, London.

q.p: Omne tulit punctum, qui miscuit utile dulci.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Henry Eversden at the Crown in Cornhil, near the Stocks-market, 1675.

div.head: The Epistle Dedicatory.
To his worthy and much honoured friend, Capt. Iohn Caine of White Chappel.
div.p:
THough idleness be a vice so bad, that nothing can be spoken disgracefull enough of it; yet the industrious busying our selves, (especially if we also trouble others) about tristes, and things which redound to little or no use, comes but little short of it in folly and absurdity. Those that know me will not accuse me of the former: and I hope that with reference to my pains in the following sheets, I shall not be charged with the latter. I think I may without vanity say, they contain not only useful and excellent matter, but much in a
little room; even a good part of the very quintessence and marrow of the famous Latin Poets. What though they were Heathens? Moses himself may take good counsell, though given by a Midianite. And the blessed Apostle Paul made use of Passages taken out of the Greek Poets, both in his Preaching and Epistles, as Acts 17.28. 1 Cor. 15.33. Tit. 1.12. This small work designed for the use and benefit of your Son and the rest of my Scholars, I humbly present and Dedicate unto your self: whose eminency and worth is such, as may give it Patronage and countenance, and from whose candor I promise my self a favourable acceptance. It is, Sir, (with my prayers to God, that you and yours may be more and more enriched with all the blessings of this and a better life,) the best evidence that at present I can give you, of the respect and gratitude due from,

closer.signed: your obliged friend and servant, John Langston.

div.head: THE PREFACE To the Courteous and Ingenious Reader.
div.p:
A Just account of the chief Occasion, Reason, and Use of this small undertaking will be, as the most proper and pertinent, so (probably) the most successfull Apology, both for the design and its Author. Omitting therefore other Artifices and Insinuations; I shall only acquaint the candid Reader, that in the execution of that difficult and weighty charge of educating youth, which God's providence hath called me to, and now for a good number of years
continued me in; I have often been projecting and contriving, (as indeed it cannot well be otherwise, with them that are conscientious and faithfull in the discharge of so great a trust:) how I might manage my Province with the greater fruit and success. Yet so, as that I still resolved to keep at a distance from the affectation of novelty.

Amongst other more substantial things, I observed how spoutaneously forward and eager Lads were in that old and ordinary exercise, commoly called, Capping of Verses. The Verses they made use of, I observed, were for the most part depending and imperfect sentences, and so yielded little other benefit, than the bare exercising of their memories. Hence, some years since I began to think, that if a competent number of the more Elegant, pithy and sententious sayings, wherewith the Poets have here and there bespangled their works, were collected; and, that the verses beginning with such or such a letter might be more readily found, alphabetically disposed; and if also the less experienced
in the Latin Tongue might be brought to understand, what they doe in this sporting way patter over; that then it would not only exercise their memories, but also conduce towards their getting words, and a facility in construing them; and moreover it would furnish them with some ready materials for their Themes and other School-exercises, without the tedious and discouraging labour of searching, they sometimes know not where. And lastly, (though other uses and benefits might be assigned,) it would store their minds with excellent precepts of morality, and other choise observations, both ornamental and usefull in their whole lives. Moved hereby, I set upon the work of Collecting, and Translating what I had collected, and made a good progress therein; and gave direction to my Scholars, that they should not confine themselves to a single verse, but be it less or more, have respect to the perfect sentence, as I had written it for them. I also appointed, especially the lower Formes, immediately after the reciting
of the Latin, to add its English also, or else that his Antagonist should not admit the verse; which when once they were used to, it became as familiar to them as otherwise. And though they were forward enough to contend this way amongst themselves, yet for their greater encouragement and benefit, I now and then heard them my self. Neither did my hope deceive me altogether, for I found good fruit and advantage hereby. Not long after, meeting in the Schools Probation, with the Title of a book which I was a stranger to, yet then used in Merchant-Taylors-School, viz. Gnomologicon poeticum; I made enquiry for it, and at last with some difficulty (it being almost out of Print,) got it. This book, I perceived, was designed by Mr. A. Ross its Author, much what to the ends before mentioned, and I was much confirmed thereby in my apprehensions of the usefulness of some such thing. But still I judged that the rendring them into English, which was wanting in Mr. Ross his book, would much promote and enlarge the benefit thereof.
For I found by too evident experience, that amongst youths, some that were capable to make themselves masters of the meaning of them in Latin, yet would satisfie themselves to be without the sweet kernel, rather than trouble themselves with the harder shell. I went on therefore with my former collections, taking in also his to my assistance, and the rather because that book of his was now grown scarce. And to save my Scholars the trouble of transcribing, I have now adventured to hand it to them from the Press; with this hope also, that if any others shall please to make trial of it with me, they may not sinde it altogether unusefull.

As for the manner of performance, you will find but few of the sentences rendred Grammatically or word for word, being warranted by that of Hor. de Arte Poetica Nec verbum verbo curabis reddere, sidus Interpres—
I judged it convenient, that having afforded the young learner no small help, by a brief hint of the chief drift and matter; scope should be left him for the trial and exercise of his own skill and ability, at a more particular and Grammatical unfolding of the sentences, and that thereby he might acquaint himself with that greater Elegancy and Emphasis which they carry with them, in their own native habit. If in the rendring of any I have missed of the true genuine sence, (as in so great variety it is not good to be too confident;) if the ingenuous Reader shall either exercise a silent candor, or give himself the greater trouble of better informing me, it must needs be look't upon as a great obligation. I thought it expedient to place those verses that begin with Ae by themselves, rather than under A, to which they naturally belong. And because there are few or none that begin with X, I have supplyed that defect with such as begin with Ex, which agrees in sound, and may doe as well. And whereas there is little use of some of
the letters in Capping, as B, C, D, F, G, &c. I was loth upon many accounts to leave out all those Verses, whose initial letter happens to be any of them: and the Teacher may appoint his Scholars to cap also sometimes out of these, without respect to the final letter.

In this Collection I have passed by some hundreds lest I should swell the book to too great a bulk and price; but I have endeavoured to take some of the best, and of most use. Those that please to make use of it, may, by having one interleav'd, add remarkable passages, as they occur, at their pleasure.

I submit the whole to the censure of the candid and Learned, and shall rejoyce if I may hereby, though in the least, be serviceable to the furthering of youth in vertue and good literature, as being, Reader,

closer.signed: Thine and their willing Servant to my power, John Langston

q.l: A Jove principium Musae: Jovis omnia plena.
WE should begin our undertakings with the invocation of God.
Ab ove majori discat arare minor.
The young Cock Crows as he hears the old one.
A cane non magno saepe tenetur aper.
A little Dog may hold a Boar.
Accidit in puncto, quod non speratur in anno.
That may happen in an hour, that may not happen in a year.
— Acceptissima semper
Munera sunt, auctor quae pretiosa facit.
The esteem we have of the person, addeth much to the worth of the gift.
Accipitres pugnant, dulce loquuntur aves.
The falling out of thieves is no harm to honest men.
Adde quod ingenuas didicisse fideliter artes,
Learning refines mens minds and manners.
Adde quod ingenium longâ rubigine laesum Torpet.
Wit not exercised grows dull.
Adde quod est senibus rerum prudentia major,
Old men are more wise, because more experienced.
Adde quod ingrato meritorum judice virtus Nostra perit,
The glory of brave actions is lost, when partial men ascribe them to fortune.
Adde quod auditae laudes, & clara parentum
Facta, movent animos, generosaque corda nepotum
Sollicitant —
The praises and famous deeds of Parents are a great spur to the minds of children.
Addit & invalidae robur facundia causae.
Eloquence gives strength to a weak cause.
Adde parum parvo, magnus acervus erit.
Many littles make a mickle.
Adgenerum Cereris sine caede & sanguine rarò
Descendunt Reges, & siccâ morte Tyranni.
Tyrants seldom dye a timely death.
— Adulator nullus amicus erit.
A flatterer is no friend.
— Adeò in teneris consuescere multum est.
It's of great concernment what we accustom our selves to in our youth.
— Agricolis redit labor actus in orbem.
The Husbandman's work is never done.
Ah quantis plena est tarda senecta malis!
How full is old age of infirmities!
Ah miser, extremum cui mortis munus iniquae
Eripitur non posse mori.
He is miserable who is not vouchsafed to dye out of his misery.
Alter rixatur de lanâ saepe caprinà.
Some make a stir about a matter of nothing.
Alterius damno qui sapit, ille sapit.
He is wise indeed, that is wise by others harms.
— Alitur vitium crescitque tegendo.
Vice increaseth by being hid and concealed.
Alba ligustra cadunt, vaccinia nigra leguntur
Snow is white yet lyes in the Dyke, pepper is black yet it hath a good smack. Prov.
— Amata relinquere durum est.
It's hard leaving things beloved.
Ampliat aetatis spatium sibi vir bonus, hoc est
Vivere bis, vitâ posse priore frui.
A good man doth in the best manner lengthen out his life: he doth as it were live twice, that enjoys the comfort of a well spent life.
An nescis longas Regibus esse manus?
Kings have long hands
Anguibus exuitur veteri cum pelle vetustas,
Snakes renew their age by casting their skin: and Stags, their Horns.
Anceps forma bonum mortalibus,
Beauty is a short and uncertain good.
Ante annos animu m{que} geras cur am{que} virilem.
Be a man in Wisdom, before you are a man in years.
Apta ferunt magnam tempora rebus opem.
A fit season much advantages our affairs.
Arbitrijnon est nostri quid quisque loquatur.
We cannot hinder people from talking.
Arcanum ne{que} tu scrutaberis ullius unquam:
C • mmissum{que} teges.
Be not inquisitive to know others secrets, nor reveal them being known.
Ardua res haec est opibus non tradere mores.
It's hard to grow rich and continue good.
Ardua per praeceps gloria tendit iter.
Glory fears not difficulties.
Ardua res vicisse alios:
It's hard to conquer others: but 'tis a greater victory to subdue our own affections.
Arma{que} in armatos sumere jura sinunt.
It's lawfull to bear arms against the armed.
Arma viri bellum{que} gerant,
Let every one meddle with his own business.
Arripuit, traxit{que} virum fax mentis honestae
Gloria. —
Glory is a great incitement to ingenuous minds.
Arte leves currus, arte regendus amor.
All things are to be guided by art.
Artibus ingenuis quaesita est gloria multis.
Many come to honour by Learning.
Asperius nihil est humili cum surgit in altum.
Set a Beggar on horseback and he will ride—
Aspera confesso verba remitte reo.
Chide not him that confesseth his fault.
Aspicis ut veniant ad candida tecta columbae,
Accipiat nullis sordida turris aves.
As doves flock to white houses, but not to sordid ones; so friends, &c.
Aspiciunt oculis superi mortalia justis.
God beholds all actions with a just eye.
Aspicis ut validus bello decesserit Hector.
In war a great person may fall as well as a meaner man.
Astutam rapido servas sub pectore vulpem.
You are a crafty companion.
At pulchrum est digito monstrari,
It's accounted a brave thing to be admired.
At sperate Deum memorem fandi atq, nefandi
God will call all to an account.
At vindicta bonum vitâ jucundius ipsâ.
Some esteem revenge sweeter than life.
At tu dum primi floret ribi temporis aetas,
Ʋtere
Improve your time while you are young.
At favor in magno saepe dolore latet.
Favour often lyes hid in great sorrow.
At praecedenti spectatur mantica tergo.
Men take more notice of others faults than their own.
At Pater ut geniti, fic nos debemus amici,
Si quod sit vitium non fastidire.
We should do by our Friends faults, as a Father by his Childs.
Attenuant vigiles corpus miser abile curae.
Care weakens the body.
Attenuant juvenum vigilatae corpora noctes
Much Night-watching weakens strong bodies.
Audax omnia perpeti Gens humana ruit per vetitum nefas.
Bold man will venture upon forbidden evills.
Aude aliquid brevibus Gyaris et carcere dignum,
Si vis esse aliquid.
He that will be some body, must run some hazard
Audentes fortuna juvat, timidos{que} repellit.
Fortune helps the adventurous.
Audendum est, fortes adjuvat ipse Deus.
God helps the couragious.
Audet et exanimum lepus infestare leonem.
An hare dare triumph over a dead Lion.
Aurea rumpunt tecta quietem,
Ʋigiles{que} trahit purpur a noctes.
Men sleep never the better for their Riches and Greatnesse.
Aurea nunc verè sunt saecula, plurimus auro
Venit honos, auro conciliandus amor.
Honour and love are sold for gold; and is not this then the golden age?
Aurea libertas auro pretiosior omni.
Liberty is better then gold.
Auro pulsa sides, auro venalia jura.
Money banisheth faithfullness and commands the laws.
Auri sacra fames, quid non mortalia cogis
Pectora!
What doth not covetousness, put men upon?
Aurum omnes victâ jam pietate colunt.
Most now a days esteem gold above godliness.

div.ab:
67 Hor.
Aut prodesse volunt, aut delectare Poetae. .
The poet will either profit or please.

q.l: Aeger dives habet nummos, sed non habet ipsum.
The sick rich man enjoys money, but enjoys not himself.
Aemilio dabitur quantum petit.
Good Lawyers cannot want clients.
Aequam memento rebus in arduis
Servare mentem, non secus ac bonis.
Be of a patient and quiet mind in adversity.
Aequo animo paenam qui meruere, ferant.
They that deserve punishment should bear it patiently.
Aequa tellus pauperi recluditur
Regum{que} pueris.
We shall lye all alike in our graves.
Aestas cum primùm fuerit componite nidos.
Make hay while the Sun shines.
Aequa tamen semper mens est, et amica voluntas,
Sit licet in natos facies austera parentum.
Parents love their children dearly, though they carry it austerely to them.
Aequa lege necessitas
Sortitur insignes & imos.
Deaths fatal necessity spares neither high nor low.
Aestuat infaelix angusto in limite mundi.
The world is too narrow for an ambitious man.
Aetas
parentum pejor avis, tulit
Nos nequiores, mox daturos
Progeniem vitiosiorem.
The world grows worse and worse, every age more wicked than other.
Aetate fruere mobili cursu fugit.
Improve your time, for it flyes away apace.
Aetas evertit turres, palatia frangit.
Time throws down towers and Palaces.
Aeterno Auctori simul adsunt omnia semper.
All things are present to God.
— Aetas Labitur occiduae pariter decliva senectae
Old men are going down the Hill apace.
Aegrotant medici, fraudantur jure periti.
Physicians themselves are sick, and Lawyers cheated.
Blanda patrum segnes facit indulgentia natos.
The fondness of parents spoils children.
Blanda truces animos fertur mollisse voluptas.
Pleasure effeminates.
Bonis quod benefit haud perit.
Kindnesses shewn to good men are not lost.
— Brevis est magni fortuna favoris.
Great favour lasts but a little while.
Candida pax homines, trux decet ira feras.
Peace becomes Men, contention wild Beasts.
Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator.
The Moneyless traveller will sing before a Thief.
Carmina proveniunt animo deducta sereno.
Verses flow not, but from a composed mind.
— Careat successibus, opto,
Quisquis ab eventu facta notanda putat.
Good success doth not prove an action good.
Caeca est temeritas quae petit casum ducem.
That's blind rashness that depends upon chance.
Casta placent superis: purâ cum veste venite,
Et mambuus puris sumite fontis aquam.
God delights in purity, in clean hands and hearts.
Causa jubet melior superos sperare secundos.
A good cause may expect Gods blessing.
Causa patrocinio non bona, pejor erit.
A bad cause is the worse for being justified and defended.
Cede repugnanti; cedendo victor abibis.
In opposition we may sometimes conquer by yielding.
Cedit amor rebus, res age, turus eris.
Mind your business, and you are safe from love.
Cedamus, leve fit, quod benè fertur onus.
A burden that is born well, becomes light.
Cernis ut ignavum corrumpant otia corpus;
Ʋt capiant vitium, ni moveantur aquae.
As standing water gathers filth, so doth sloth corrupt body and mind.
Certus amor morumest, formam populabitur aetas
Good qualities are a more permanent foundation for love, than beauty is.
Certandum est, nulli veniunt sine marte triumphi;
Et nisi certanti nulla corona datur.
There's no conquering without fighting.
Certum est in cineres corpus mortale reverti,
Sed tamen aeternus non erit ille sopor,
It's certain we shall all dye, but we shall rise again.
— Clades scire qui refugit suas,
Gravat timorem: dubia plus torquent mala.
It's no wisdome to avoid the knowledge of our misfortunes: doubtful evills torment the more.
Caelum non animum mutat, quitrans mare currit.
Travellers change their climate, but not their disposition.
Coepisti meliùs quàm desinis; ultima primis
Cedunt: dissimilis hic vir, & ille puer.
You begun well, but end ill: a hopeful youth hath prov'd but a bad man.
Commoditas omnis sua fert incommoda secum.
There's no convenience without an inconvenience.
Conscia mens ut cui{que} sua est, ita concipit intra
Pectora pro meritis spem{que} metum{que} suis.
As a man's conscience is, so are his inward hopes or sears.
Conscia mens rectifamae mendacia ridet.
A clear conscience despiseth slanders.
Consule, queis aetas longa magistra fuit.
Ask counsell of those that are elderly and experienced.
Contudit ingenium patientia longa malorum.
Long sufferings dull the wit.
Conveniet nulli, qui secum diffidet ipse.
He that agrees not with himself, will agree with none.
Conteritur ferrum, silices tenuantur ab usu,
Use wears away stones and iron.
Conscius ipse sibi de se putat omnia dici.
A guilty person thinks every body whispers about him.
Clodius accusat maechos. —
Vice corrects sin.
— Continuâ messe senescit ager.
All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.
Corpora vertuntur, nec quod fuimusve, sumusve,
Cras erimus.
Our bodies are continually changing.
Corpora magnanimo satis est prostrâsse leoni.
A noble mind will spare him that submits himself.
— Citius nos
Corrumpunt vitiorum exempla domestica. —
Domestick bad examples soonest corrupt us.
Crede mihi benè qui latuit, benè vixit, et intra
Fortunam debet quis{que} manere suam.
A private life is a safe life.
Conveniunt rebus nomina saepe suis.
Names and natures often agree.
Credere fallaci gravis est dementia samae.
It's a madness to believe every common report.
Crede mihi, res est vir pretiosa bonus.
A good man is a precious thing.
Crescit amor nummi, quantum ipsa pecunia crescit.
The more money increaseth, the more the love of it increaseth also.
Crescentem sequitur cura pecuniam,
Majorum{que} fames.
As riches increase, so do also cares and desires of more.
Cui placet alterius, sua nimirum estiodio sors.
Another's condition pleaseth us better than our own.
Cum feriant unum, non unum fulmina terrent.
The thunderbolt smites one, but affrights many.
Cum mercede labor gratior esse potest.
Reward encourageth to labour.
— Celsae graviore casu
Decidunt turres, feriunt{que} summos
Fulmina montes.
The higher a man stands, the more in danger is he of a fall, and the greater will the fall be.
Crescunt Divitiae, tamen
Curtae nescio quid semper abest rei.
Though riches increase, yet the covetous man always wants something.
Cuncta priùs tentanda, sed immedicabile vultus
Ense recidendum, ne pars sincera trahatur.
All means are to be tried, but an incurable member must be cut off, least the sound part be insected also.
Cuncta manus avidas fugient haeredis, amico
Quae dederis animo.
A man is his own best Executor.
Cur nemo est Hecaten, nulla est quae ceperat Irum?
Nempe quòd alter egens, altera pauper erat.
Poor men are little sought after or regarded.
Cura vigil, labor ossa domans, dolor anxius, omnem
Sollicitant hominum vitam.—
Care, Labour, and Sorrow, torture poor man.
Cura viris levibus rerum solet esse novarum.
Light persons mind novelty.
Cura viris gravibus rerum solet esse suarum.
Solid persons mind their own business.
Curae leves loquuntur. ingentes stupent.
Light cares speak, but great ones stupifie.
Cur in amicorum vitijs tam cernis acutum,
Quam aut aquila, aut serpens Epidaurius?
Why are you so quick-sighted in your friends faults?
Curando sieri quaedam majora videmus
Ʋulnera, quae melius non tetigisse fuit.
Some wounds heal better of themselves, than by much tampering.
Curia consilio constabilita senum est.
Elderly mens counsell is safest.
Curia pauperibus clausa est, dat census honores.
Poor men can have no admission at Court.
Custode & curâ natura potentior om ni.
Nature will be too hard, for any watch or guard.
Dat Deus immiti cornua curta bovi
Curst cowes have short horns.
Da requiem, requietus ager benè credita reddit.
The fallow field from bearing corn doth cease A while, but after yields the more increase.
Da spatium, tenuem{que} moram; màle cuncta ministre,
Impetus.
Rash hasty violence spoiles all.
Dantur opes nullis nune nisi divitibus.
Men love to grease the Fat Sow in the tail.
Dat veniam corvis, vexat censura columbas.
Some may with more safety steal an horse, than others look over the hedge.
De malè quaesitis vix gaudet tertius haetes.
An ill gotten estate seldome comes to the third generation.
Decrescit requie virtus, sed crescit agendo.
Vertue increaseth by exercising it.
Dedecorant pravi mores, quem vultus honestat.
Handsome is he that handsome does.
Degeneres animos timor arguit.—
Fear argues a low spirit.
Delphinum sylvis appingit, fluctibus aprum.
He acts by contraries.
Deni{que} non parvas animo dat gloria vires,
Et faecunda facit pectora laudis amor.
Glory and praise, mens minds do raise.
Deni{que} non omnes ea dem mir antur amant{que}.
Every man hath his humour.
Desine fata Deum slecti sperare precando.
What God will, must be.
Desinat elatis quisquam considere rebus.
Trust not in Riches and Prosperity
Desidiâ virtus paulatim evicta senescit.
Vertue not exercised languisheth.
Difficile est fateor, sed tendit in ardua virtus.
A vertuous mind is not discouraged by difficulty.
Difficile est tristi singere mente jocum.
It's difficult to jest, being with grief opprest.
Dignior est qui se, quam qui fortissima vincit
Moenia.
Greater is he that conquers himself, than he which conquers a City.
Diruit, aedificat, mutat quadrata rotundis.
He is as wavering as the weathercock.
Dimidium facti, qui benè caepit, habet.
Well begun is half done.
Discite quos sursum volvit rota ponere fastus.
You rising men, your pride learn for to lay aside.
Diversae rapiunt animum in contraria curae.
Divers cares distract the mind.
Divitis ad manes nil feret umbra suos.
The rich can carry nothing out of the World.
Divitae grandes homini sunt vivere parcè.
It's great Riches to live sparingly.
Dos est magna parentium
Virtus.—
The Vertue of Parents is a good pordon.
Dulcis inexpertis cultura potentis amici.
They're unex perienc'd that think it sweet to have much to do with great men.
Dum juvat, & vultu ridet fortuna sereno;
Indelibatas cuncta sequuntur opes.
While Fortune favours, a man shall have friends.
— Dociles imitandis
Turpibus ac pravis omnes sumus. —
We are apt to learn that which is bad.
Durate & vosmet rebus servate secundis.
Hold out, it may be better hereafter.
Dulciùs ex ipso fonte bibuntur aquae.
Water is sweetest at Fountain head.
Dum vitant stulti vitia in contraria currunt.
While soolish men one vice do shun, Into another ost they run.
Dummodo sit Dives, barbarus ipse placet.
Any one pleaseth so that he be rich.
Dum vires anni{que} sinunt tolerate laborem,
Nam veniet tacito curva senecta pede.
Work while you are young and lusty, old age will creep on apace.
Dum spectant laesos oculi laeduntur & ipsi,
Multa{que} corporibus transitione nocent.
Some company is insections.
Dum fortuna juvat, caveto tolli, Dum fortuna tonat, caveto mergi.
When Fortune smiles, of pride beware. And though it frown do not despair.
Durum, sed levius fit patientiâ, Quicquid corrigere est nefas.
Though hard, yet patience will make light, What to amend exceeds our might.
Egregios cumulare libros, praeclara supellex:
Good books are good housholdstuff.
Eheu quam levibus pereunt ingentia causis?
Great things may fall by causes small.
Enumer at miles vulnera, pastor oves.
Every man to his trade.
— En quò discordia cives
Peduxit miseros!
To what a miserable state hath discord brought a People!
Ergo sollichae tu causa pecunia vitae es.
Money causeth care and trouble.
Eripere vitam nemo non homini potest,
At nemo mortem.
Every one may take away life, none free from Death.
Eripit interdum, modo dat medicina salutem.
Physick sometimes does good, sometimes harm.
Errare est hominis, sed non persistere.—
It's an humane thing to erre, but not to persevere.
Esse bonum facile est, ubi quod vetat esse remotum es.
It's easie to be good where there's no temptation to the contrary.
Est{que} pati paenam quàm meruisse minus.
It's better to be afflicted than sin.
Est vīrtus placitis abstinuisse bonis.
That's vertue, when we deny our selves in those things that please us.
Est pietas suprema Deo parere, nec ullum
Gratius est sacrum, nec victima sanctior ulla.
Obedience is better than sacrifice.
Est opus ardentem fraenis arcere juventam.
Youth must be restrained.
Est aliqua ingrato meritum exprobrare voluptas.
It's some pleasure to upbraid an unthankfull person with my kindness.
Est & in incessu pars non temnenda decoris.
It's comely to have an handsome gate.
Est vitae ac pariter janua lingua necis.
Life and Death are in the power of the Tongue.
Est modus in rebus, sunt certi deni{que} fines,
Quos ultra citra{que} nequit consistere rectum.
There is a mean in things, and certain lines, Within which vertue still it self consines.
Est inter Tanaim quiddam socerum{que} Ʋiselli.
There's difference between staring and stark mad.
Est quoddam prodire tenus, si non datur ultra.
It's something to have gone so far, if more be denied.
Et benè apud memores veteris stat gratia facti.
Old kindness should not be forgotten.
Et non sentitur sedulitate labor.
A diligent Mind, counts Labour light and easie.
Et latro & cautus praecingitur ense viator,
Ille sed insidias, hic sibi portat opem.
Both Thief and Traveller a Sword do take, The one for harm, t'other defence to make.
Et quò non possum corpore, mente feror.
Where my body can't be, my mind shall.
Et mala sunt vicina bonis, errore sub illo
Provitio virtus crimina saepe tulit.
Vertue is so counterfeited by vice, that often the one is mistaken for the other.
Et videt & justâ librat Deus omnia lance.
God sees and weighs all things in a just ballance.
Et genus & formam regina pecunia donat.
If Gold your coffers fill, you shall be what you will.
Et quis non causas mille doloris habet?
Who has not a thousand causes for Grief?
Et cum fortunâ stat{que} cadit{que} sides.
A mans Credit and his Friends stand and fall with his Fortune.
Et certam praesens vix habet hora fidem.
Time is very uncertain.
Et neglecta solent incendia sumere vires.
Fire neglected gets more strength.
Et si non prosunt singula, multa juvant.
Many may do something, but what's one?
Et genus & virtus nisi cum re vilior alga est.
A good descent and vertue it self are by many esteemed little worth, if Riches be wanting.
Et semel emissum volat irrevocabile verbum.
Words once spoken cannot be recalled.
Et mihi res, non me rebus submittere conor.
I would be Master of my estate, not a Slave to it.
Et patrum in natos abeunt cum semine mores.
The Son often proves like the Father.
Et tibi jam venient cani, formose, capilli:
The comliest Hair will ere long grow gray:
Et placitus rugis vultus aratus erit.
And the beautifullest Face will grow wrinckled.
Eventus varios res nova semper habet.
A new matter hath various events
— Est quaedam, flere voluptas.
It's some pleasure to weep,

div.head: F

q.l: Fac modo consuescas, nihil assuetudine majus.
Accustome thy self, than which nothing is of more force.
— Facilis descensus Averni.
The way to Hell is broad and easie.
— Facies, non uxor amatur.
Beauty is with many the only ground of love.
— Faciunt hi plura, sed illos
Defendit numerus.—
The great number of offenders is often the cause of their impunity.
— Facilis reperitur causa dolendi.
Sorrow comes unsent for.
Fallitur, egregio quisquis sub principe credit
Servitium; nunquam liberta; gratior extat,
Quam sub rege pio. —
To be under a good Prince is no servitude.
Fallitur augurio spes bona saepe suo.
Our hope-well often deceives us.
Fallere credentem non est operosa puellam Gloria. —
It's no glory to deceive a credulous maid.
Fallit enim vitium specie virtutis & umbrâ.
Vice deceives us under the colour of vertue.
Fallitur in dubijs hominum solertia rebus.
Men's cunning deceives them in doubtfull maters.
Fama, malum quo non aliud velocius ullum,
Mobilitate viger, vires{que} acquirit eundo.
Reports lose nothing by carrying.
Faftus inest pulchris, sequitur{que} superbia formam.
Beauty and pride often keep company.
Fata manent omnes, omnes expectat avarus
We must all dye.

div.l: Portitor, & turbae vix satis una ratis.

q.l: — Fas est & ab hoste doceri.
We may learn even of an enemy.
Felices frustra nobis promittimus annos,
Semper enim curae tristitiae{que}; premunt.
We're apt our selves to promise happy years, But still we're vext with griefs, and cares, & sears.
Felix quem faciunt aliena pericula cautum.
Happy is he whom other mens harms make wary.
Felices ter & amplius
Quos irrupta tenet copula, nec malis
Divulsus querimonijs
Suprema citius solvet amor die.
Thrice happy that married couple, that live lovingly together to their lives end.
Felix qui proprijs aevum transegit in arvis
Ipsa domus puerum quem videt, ipsa senem.
Happy is he that from youth to old age hath lived in his own Farm.
Fertilis assiduo si non renovetur aratro,
Nil nisi cum spinis gramen habebit ager.
Without culture ground will bring forth no good Fruit.
Fertilior seges est alienis semper in agris;
Men think others goods better than their own.
Ferreus assiduo consumitur annulus usu.
Use wears away Iron it self.
Ferrum tuetur principem, meliùs fides.
Faithfullness is a better defence to a Prince, than the Sword.
Faemineâ in poenâ nullum est memorabile nomen.
It's no honour to beat a Woman.
Festinare nocet, nocet & cunctatio saepe.
Both too much haste and too much delay are dangerous.
Fidite virtuti, fortuna fugacior undis.
Rely on Vertue not on unconstant Fortune.
Firma valent per se, nullum{que} Machaona quaerunt,
Ad medicam dubius confugit aeger opem.
The whole have no need of the Physician, but they that are sick.
Fistula dulce canit, volucrem dum decipit auceps.
Fair words make Fools saine.
Flebile principium melior fortuna sequuta est.
What begins sorrowfully may end joyfully.
Flectitur iratus voce rogante Deus.
God is moved by our prayers.
Flumina magna vides parvis de fontibus orta.
Great matters sometimes arise from small beginnings.
Fortia{que} adversis opponite pectora rebus.
Be valiant in adversity.
— Flagrantior aequo
Non debet dolor esse viri, nec vulnere major.
We ought not to grieve more than the matter requires.
Flectere si nequeo superos, Acheronta movebo.
What bad men cannot do by right, they'l do by wrong.
Forma bonum fragile est, quantum{que} accedit ad ann •
Fit minor, & spatio carpitur ipsa suo.
Beauty is but a sading flower.
Fortes creantur fortibus, & bonis:
Est in juvencis, est in equis patrum
Virtus: nec imbellem feroces
Progenerant aquilae columbam.
Commonly Sons inherit their Fathers nobler Spirit: The same we partly see 'mongst Beasts and Birds
Fortuna opes auferre, non animum potest.
Fortune may wealth destroy, but can't the mind annoy. to be.
Fortuna fortes metuit, ignavos premit.
The bold do fortune scare, crusht by it dull souls are
Fortunam superat virtus, prudentia fatum.
Vertue and Wlsdome are above Fortune and Fate.
Formosis levitas semper amica fuit.
Beauty and Levity are ost-times near Neighbours.
— Forsan & haec olim meminisse juvabit.
It will delight us hereafter to think on our past dangers.
Frangit & attollit vires in milite causa.
A good cause adds courage to Souldiers: a bad one dis-spirits them.
Frangitur ipsa suis Roma superba bonis.
Proud Rome falls by its own Prosperity.
— Fratrum quo{que} gratia rara est.
Brothers seldome agree.
Fronte capillata est, post est occasio calva.
Occasions forelock must be laid hold on, it's bald behind.
Fructus honos oneris; fructus honoris onus.
Burdens produce Honour, and Honour produceth a Burden.
— Frustra vitium vitaveris illud
Si te alio pravum detorseris. —
It's vain to exchange one vice for another.
— Fugit irreparabile tempus.
Time flees away and can never be recalled.
— Furor est post omnia per dere naulum.
It's no wisdom to throw away the helve after the hatchet.
— Furor arma ministrat.
Rage will easily find weapons.
— Furor ira{que} mentem Praecipitant. —
Fury and Anger drive the Mind headlong.
Gaudia principium sunt nostri saepe doloris.
Much joy often ushers in Great sorrow.
Gaudia post luctus veniunt, post gaudia luctus.
After joy comes sorrow, and after sorrow joy.
Gaudia non remanent sed fugitiva volant.
Joyes quickly vanish.
Gaudent securi narrare pericula nautae.
The Mariner being Safe rejoyceth to tell of his dangers.
Gloria quantalibet, quid erit, si gloria tantum 〈◊〉
Honour how great soever, what is'e if bare Honour?
Grata superveniet, quae non sperabitur, hora.
A better time many come than we look for.
— Grande doloris
Ingenium est, miseris{que} venit solertia rebus.
Misery sometimes makes men ingenious.
Grata Deo non sunt fumantia thura, nec arae,
Nec sacra, si cordis religione carent.
In all our Services God chiefly looks at our hearts.
Gratia ab officio, quod mora tardat, abest.
Delayed courtesies are little thankworthy.
Gratia quae taráa est, in grata est; gratia namqu ••
Quae fieri properat, gratia grata magis.
A kindness performed with speed and readiness is most acceptable.
Gratior est pulchro veniens è corpore virtus.
Vertue shines most, when in a comely person seen.
— Grex totus in agris
Ʋnius porciscabie cadit. —
One scabbed sheep mars the whole flock.
Gutta cavat lapidem, consumitur annulus usu.
Use wears away stones and iron.
Haud facile emergunt, quorum virtutibus obstat
Res angusta domi. —
Vertue can hardly mount, when clogged by The pressing weight of Servile poverty.
Haud ullas portabis opes Acherontis ad undas.
You shall carry none of your Riches out of the World with you.
Haud facile invenies multis è millibus unum,
Virtutem pretium qui putet esse sui.
Few admire Vertue for its own Beauty, or think it to be its own sufficient reward.
Haec virtus vidua est quam non patientia firmat.
Vertue must be accompanied and established by patience.
Helleborum srustra cum jam cutis aegra tumebit
Poscentos videas: venienti occurrite morbo.
Use meanes against a disease at first, least afterwards it be too late.
Hei mihi quod nullis amor est med cabilis herbis
No physick can cure Love-sickness.
Heu quam difficile est crimen non prodere vultu!
It's hard to forbear bewraying our guiltiness by our countenance.
Heu quantum misero poenae mens conscia donat!
A guilty Conscience is a great torment.
Heu patior relis vulnera facta meis.
I my self am the cause of my own sorrow.
Heu nihil invitis sas quenquam fidere Divis.
If God deny his help nothing will avail.
Hei mihi difficile est imitari gaudi falsa.
It's hard to make shew of a false joy.
— Hic murus abencus esto,
Nil conscire sibi, nullâ pallescere culpâ.
A good Conscience is a brazen wall.
Hic segete: veniunt, illic folicius uvae,
Every ground best beareth its proper fruit.
Horrea formicae tendant ad inania nunquam,
Nullus ad amissas ibit amicus opes.
The poor shall have few Friends.
Humanae{que} memor sortis, quae tollit eosdem
Et premit; incertas ipse verere vices.
Men rise and fall, for all things are Uncertain: think on this and fear.
Humi jacentem scelera non intrant casam,
Tutus{que} mensà carpitur augustâ cibus.
The mean condition is the safest from danger.
— Huic fidus Achates
Sit comes, & paribus curis vestigia figat.
A Faithfull Friend is a great help.
Jam cras hesternum consumpsimus, ecce aliud cras.
Many morrows are come and gone, Yet still to morrow is our tone.
Jam{que} nocens serrum, ferro{que} nocentius aurum
Predierat.
Iron hath done much mischief, but Gold more.
Idem amor exitio est pecori, pecoris{que} magistro.
The same love pines both the Cattell and their owner.
— Ibi nulla sides est, ubi nullus amor.
There's no trust where there's no love.
Jejunus raro stomachus vulgaria temnit.
An Hungry Stomack will not find sault with ordinary Diet.
Ignorat quid distent aera lupinis.
He knowes not an Hawk from an Handsaw.
— Ignoti nulla cupido.
What we know not, we desire not.
— Ignavis precibus fortuna repugnat.
God lends but little Ear unto a slothfull Prayer.
Iliacos intra muros peccatur & extra
City and Countrey, Friends and Foes all have their sins.
Ille crucem precium sceleris tulit, hic dia dema.
Some are advanced for what others are punished.
Illud quod medium est at{que} inter utrum{que} probatur.
That which is in the midst is best.
Illud amicitiae sanctum & venerabile nomen
Nunc tibi pro vili, sub pedibus{que} jacet.
That venerable name of Friendship now is of no account with you.
Illud amicitiae quondam venerabile nomen
Prostat, & in quaestu pro meretrice sedet.
That venerable thing friendship is also now a days set to sale.
Ille dolet verè qui sine teste dolet.
Then sorrow is most true when not exposd to View.
Imberbis juvenis tandem custode remoto,
Gaudet equis canibus{que} & aprici gramine campi:
C •• reus in vitium flecti, monitoribus asper:
Ʋrilium tardus provisor, prodigus aeris:
Sublimis, cupidus{que} & amata relinquere pernix.

Th'unbearded youth once from his Guardian free, Loves Dogs and Horses, and i'th' field to be: To Vice like Wax, to take good Counsell hard, And to his own good hath but slow regard: Prodigall, Haughty, to desire soon mov'd, And then as swift to leave what he hath lov'd.
Immodicus risus non est sapientis. —
Too much Laughter discovers Folly.
Immodicis brevis est aetas, & rara senectus.
Those that are immoderate seldome live long.
Immortalia ne speres monet annus, & almum
Quae rapit hora diem.
That thou must dye, the year doth say And Hours which draw the winged day.
— Immensa est, sinem{que} potentia Coeli Non habet.—
God's power is without bounds or end.
Impatiens animus nec adhuc tractabilis arte,
Respait, at{que} odio verba monentis habet.
An impatient person is uncapable of Counsel.
Impedit ira animum, ne possit cernere verum.
Anger binders from seeing the Truth.
Impediunt certam medicamina crehra salutem.
Much Physick prejudiceth the health.
Imperat aut servit collecta pecunia cuiq{que}.
Money is a Servant to some, but a Master to others.
Impia sub dulci melle venena latent.
Poysonous designs oft lye hid under sweet words.
Impiger extremos currit mercator ad Indos
Per mare pauperiem fugiens, per saxa, per ignes
Through Stroms, and Rocks, and Fires the Mer-To sarthest India run, his chests to fill.
Impius haec tam culta novalia miles habebit?
Barbarus has segetes? —
Must wicked souldiers enjoy our fields and corn?
Imprimis venerare Deum —
Let God have your first and best.
Improbe amor, quid non mortalia pectora cogis!
What doth not wicked love put men upon!
In freta collectas alta quid addis aquas?
Why carry you coles to New-castle?
In causâ facili cuivis licet esse diserto.
In an easie cause any one may be cloquent.
In prolem dilata ruunt perjuria patris,
Et poenam merito filius ore luit.
Children oft fare the worse for their Fathers wickedness.
In sobolem transire patris cum semine virtus
Saepe solet. —
Vertuous parents are most like to have vertuous children,
In magnis voluisse sat est. —
In great things 'tis somewhat to have but a will.
In pretio pretium nunc • st, dat census honores,
Census amicitias; pauper ubi{que} jacet.
It's money make the mare to go.
In commune jubes siquid, censesq, tenendum
Primus jussa subi, tunc observantior aequi
Fit populus.—
If you would have good orders kept, then keep them your self first.
In vitium ducet culpae fuga, si caret arte.
The avoiding of faults leads to greater faults, if not guided by wisdome.
In pejora datur, suadet{que} licentia luxum.
Men are the worse for licentious liberty.
Incidit in Scyllam cupiens vitare Charybdim.
Out of the frying-pan into the fire.
Indulget fortuna malis ut laedere possit.
Wicked men prosper to their own hurt.
Incubuit nunquam coelestis flamma salictis,
Nec parvi frutices ir am mecuere tonantis;
Ingentes quercus, annosas fulminat ornos.
From Lightning and from Thunder stroaks
Poor shrubs and willows safer are:
Let the proud Ash and sturdy Oakes,
Whose danger greater is, beware.
Infirmi est animi exigni{que} voluptas Ʋltio.
Revenge is a pleasure to a low spirit.
Injiciet{que} manus formae dammosa senectus,
Quae strepitum passu non faciente venit.
Old-age, sair Beauty's spightful enemy,
Upon us steals a pace, though silently.
Iniqua nunquam regna perpetuo manent.
An ill usurped throne, to last is seldome known.
Ingenium quamvis fuerit pretiosius auro,
At nunc barbaria est grandis habere nihil.
Excellent parts in a poor man are now a days little regarded.
Inquinat egregios adjuncta superbia mores.
Pride spoyls brave accomplishments.
— Insano nemo in amore videt.
Love is blind.
Insanus medio flumine quaeris • quas.
You cannot see Wood for Trees.
Inter utrum{que} volat dubij, victoria pennis.
In War, Victory sometimes inclines to one side, sometimes to the other.
Inter Pigmaeos non pudet esse brevem.
Amongst Dwarss it's no shame to be short.
Inter utrum{que} tene, medio tutissimus ibis.
In most things on each hand extreams there be,
The middle path is most from danger free.
Intempestivè qui monet, ille nocet.
An unseasonable admonition does more harm than good.
Interdum lachrymae pondera vocis habent.
There oftentimes appears
A kind of voice in tears.
— Interdum miscentur tristia laetis.
Here we meet with little joy,
But what of grief hath some alloy.
— Interdum & vulgus videt, est ubi peccet.
The common People are sometimes in the right, sometimes in the wrong.
Ingenio formae damna rependo meae.
By Wit I make amends for my defect in Beauty.
— Inspice late,
Florentes quondam luxus quas verterit arces.
Luxury overthrows Kingdomes.
— Inops audacia tuta est.
They that have nothing can lose nothing.
Interpone tuis interdum gaudia curis.
Mingle recreation with your labour.
Invadunt urbem somno vino{que} sepultam.
Enemies easily invade the City, when buried in sleep and wine.
Invenies aliumsi te hic fastidit Alexis.
If one won't, another will.
Invenies multos, si res tibi floret, amicos.
If you have golden ore,
You shall have Friends good store.
Invida fatorum series; summis{que} negatum Stare diu.
Greatness is seldome lasting.
Invidiae morbo praesens malè judicat aetas:
Judicium melius posterit atis erit.
The present age doth some their due praise grudge,
Of whom posterity will better judge.
Invidiâ Siculi non invenere Tyranni
Tormentum majus.
Sicilian Tyrants never yet could find
A greater torment than an envious mind.
Invidus alterius rebus macrescit opimis.
Another's happiness is death
To him that draws an envious breath.
Invidiâ, vel amore vigil tor quebere.—
Fond love or envy in man's brest
Torment him, and exile his rest.
Invidiam nimio culiu vitare memento.
Do not procure envy by too much bravery.
Ipsa dies quando{que} parens, quando{que} noverca est.
The very same day, now a Parent kind,
Then a Stepmother cruel, we do find.
Ipsa quidem virtus sibimet pulcherrima merces.
Vertue is its own reward.
Ipsa quidem virtus pretium sibi, sola{que} late
Fortunae secura nitet.
Vertue such native worth and glory hath,
That it regards not Fortun's stormy wrath.
Ipsa quo{que} assiduo labuntur tempora motu.
Time slides away with a continuall motion.
Inde datae leges ne fortior omnia posset.
For this cause wholsome laws were made,
That Might should not poor Right invade.
Ipse licèt venias musis comitatus, Homere,
Si nihil attuleris, ibis, Homere, foràs.
Homer himself, though ne're so much extold,
If Moneyless, shall welcome have but cold.
Ira furor brevis est—
Anger is a short madness.
Ira cadat cum sole, at non cum sole resurgat.
Let your Anger set with the Sun, but not rise again with it.
Interdum doctâ plus valet arte malum.
Art cannot sometimes cure an evil.
Ira odium generat, concordia nutrit amorem.
Anger begets hatred, concord nourisheth love.
Irus & est subitò, qui modo Craesus erat.
Some fall from great riches 〈◊〉 great poverty and distress.
Is sapiens, qui so ad casus accommodat omnes.
He is wise, that prepares and accommodates himself to all hazards.
Judicis officium est, ut res, ita tempora rerum
Quaerere; quaesito tempore tutus erit.
A judge should enquire, not only into matters but into the circomstance of time.
Judicium reddit verum narratio vera.
A true stating of the ease conduceth to a true determination of the matter.
Jurgia bilem acuunt, convitia pectus acerbant.
Foul words breed bad blood.
Judicium metuit sibi mens malè conscia justum.
A guilty Conscience must needs fear a just judgment.
Judice me, fraus est concessa repellere fwraudem.
To deceive the deceiver is no deceit.
Justum & tenacem propositi virum
Non civium ardor prava jubentium,
Non vultus instantis Tyranni
Mente quatit solidâ: ne{que} Auster &c.
An honest and resolved man,
Neither a peoples tumults can,
Neither a Tyrants indignation,
Uncenter from his fast foundation;
Nor storms &c.
Justitia utilibus rectum praepouere suadet.
Honesty is to be preferred before prosit.
Juvenile vitium est regere non posse impetum.
It's a youthfull fault not to be able to rule his eager affections.
Juvenilis ardor impetu primo furit;
Languescit idem facile, nec durat dia.
Young men are hot at first, but soon cool again.
Labimur saevo rapiente fato.
We do apace decay
Fate driving us away.
Labitur occultè, fallit{que} volubilis aetas.
Time slides away we know not how, and deceiveth poor man.
Labitur exiguo quod partum est rempore longo.
That which is long in getting is oftentimes soon spent.
Labitur admissis heu celer annus equis.
The year passeth away swistly.
— Labor ovmia vincit
Improbus. —
Labour overcomes all things.
Laedere qui potuit, predesse aliquando valebit.
He that can do us an injury, may one time or other do a kindness.
Lanificas nulli tres exorare puellas
Contigit, observant quem statuere diem.
None can avoid Death.
Laetitia juvenem, frons decet tristis senem.
In youth as comely cheerfullness appears,
As profound gravity in deeper years.
Laesa pudlcitia est nullâ repar abilis arte.
Chastity once lost is not to be repaired.
Laetius est quoties magno sibi constat honestum.
A worthy action, the more it costs, the more it pleaseth a vertuous mind.
Latius regnes avidum domando
Spiritum, quam si Lybiam remotis
Gadibus jungas, & uter{que} Poenus Serviat uni.
He that restrains his covetous soul
Rules more, than if he should controul
Both Land and Sea; and adde a West-Indies toth' East.
Latrantem stomachum benè lenit cum sale panis.
A crust of bread is sweet
To th' hungry appetite.
Laudamus veteres, sed nostris utimur annis.
The lives of Ancestors we praise,
But yet live after our own wayes.
Laudat venales, qui vult extrudere merces.
The Fish-woman will not cry stinking Fish.
Laudatas ostendit avid Junonia pennas.
The gay-plum'd Peacock would have all to know
How fine she is, and therefore makes her show. Or.
Laudatas homini volucris Junonia pennas
Explicat. —
The more the haughty Peacock is extold
The more she will her sinery unfold.
Laus vera humili saepe contigit viro.
Humble men ost gain the truest honour.
—Laudata{que} virtus
Crescit, & immensum gloria calcar habet.
Glory is a great spur to ingenuous minds.
Leniter, ex merito quicquid patiare, ferendum est.
It is fit that thou should'st hear patiently, what thou sufferest deservedly.
Levis est dolor, qui capere consilium potest,
Et clepere sese.
It's light sorrow that can take counsell.
Laetus in praesens animus, quod ultra est
Oderit curare: & amara laeto
Temperet risu. Nihil est ab omni
Parte beatum.
Let minds of any joy possest,
Sweeten therewith whatever gall
Is mixt: no soul that e're was blest, Was blest in all.
Leve est miserias ferre, per ferre est grave.
To exercise a thorough lasting patience under afflictions is difficult.
—Levius laedit, quicquid praevideris antè •
Foreseen evils afflict the less.
Laudatur meritò laudator, amatur amator.
They that love and commend others, are worthy of love and commendation from others.
Libertas quoniam nulli jam restat amanti,
Nullus liber erit siquis amare potest.
He that is in love, is not his own man.
Libertas est summa bonis sub principe justo.
Subjection to a just Prince is no infringement of our freedome.
Libertatis amor, miserum quid decipis orbem?
The love of liberty deceives the world.
—Licuit, semper{que} licebit
Parcere personis, dicere de vitijs.
It never did, nor will deserve just blame
Vice to reprove, and not the persons name.
—Linguà mali pars pessima servi.
An ill tongue is the worst part of a bad servant.
Lis est cum formâ magna pudicitiae.
Beauty and Chastity seldome agree.
Lis mihimis verbis interdum maxima crescit.
Sometimes from small words ariseth great strife and contention.
Litem inserre cave, cum quo tibi gratia juncta est.
Let there no bickerings be
Betwixt thy Friend and thee.
Littore quot conchae, tot sunt in amore dolores;
Quae patimur, multo spicula felle madent.
There are many sorrows, and much gall in love.
Linquenda tellus, & domus, & placens
Ʋxor; ne{que} barum quas colis arborum,
Te, praeter invisas Cupressos,
Ʋlla brevem Dominum sequetur.
Thou must sorego thy lands and goods
Thy pleasing Wise: nor of thy woods
(Dying) shall any follow thee,
But the sad funerall Cypress tree.
Livor tabificum malis venenum
Intactis vorat ossibus medullas,
Et totum bibit artubus cruorem.
That banefull poyson, envious spite
Devours the inward marrow quite,
And it self slily entertains
With draughts of blood out of the veins.
Livor & inviso carpere dente solet.
Malice will be carping.
Livor iners vitium, mores non exit in altos,
Ʋt{que} latens imâ vipera serpit humo.
An envious spirit is a low ignoble spirit, and comes to little.
Livor & ambitio magnatum insida{que} vulgi
Mobilitas, rerum semper studiosa novarum,
Sollicitant regnantum animos.
The envy and ambition of Nobles, unconstancy and desire of novelty in the Vulgar, cause much trouble to Rulers.
Longa mora est nobis omnis, quae gaudia differt.
Long seemeth that delay,
Which keeps our joyes away.
Longa dies ignavo homini nox longa videtur.
Day and Night seem long and tedious to a slothfull person.
Longa dies marmor solidum contrivit & aera.
The solid Marble and Brass wear away in time.
Longa dies homini docuit parere leones,
Longa dies molli saxa peredit aqua.
Time teacheth Lions Man for to obey,
Time with sofe Water eats the Rocks away.
Longius aut propius sors sua quem{que} manet.
Impartial Death standeth to some more nigh,
From others farther off; but all must dye.
—Longo revirescit in aevo Gloria.—
A mans honour once blasted is long before i • flourisheth again.
Loripedem rectus derideat, Aethiopem albus.
We should be clear of the saults our selves, for which we deride or blame others.
Ludere qui nescit, campestribus abstinet armis.
Who knowes not how his armes to use,
May sit still, and the game refuse.
Ludit in humanis divina potentia rebus.
Gods power seems as it were to sport it self in humane affairs.
Ludus enim genuit trepidum certamen & iram.
Even play oftentimes breeds wrath and contention.
—Ludi quo{que} semina praebent. Nequitiae.—
The seeds of wickedness appear and spring up ev'n in play.
Lurida terribiles miscent aconita novercae.
Stepmothers often exercise cruelty towards poor children.
Luxuries nunquam parvo contenta paratu.
Spare diet will not satisfie
Him that is giv'n to luxury.
Luxuriant animi rebus plerun{que} secundis
The mind doth oft luxuriant grow,
When wealth and honour overflow.
Luxuries vitijs odijs{que} superbia vertit Regna.
Luxury and pride overthrow flourishing Kingdomes.
Luxuries praedulce malum, quae dedita semper
Corporis arbi •• ijs, heberat caligine sensus,
Membra{que} Circaeis essae ninat acrius herbis.
Voluptuous luxury yielding delight
So correspondent to the appetite,
Men more effeminates, bewitches, harms,
Then ever Circe could with all her charms.
— Lucri honus est odor, ex re
Qualibet.—
Gain, whencesoe're it springs,
A gratefull odour brings.
Macte nov virtute puer, sic itur ad astra.
Proceed in thy Heroick vertue for that's the way to Glory.
Magna repente ruunt, summa cadunt subitò.
Great things do quickly fall,
And greatest soon'st of all.
Magna petis, Phaeton, & quae non viribus istis
Munera conveniunt, nec tam puerilibus annis.
A charge too great, fond youth thou dost desire,
Which does morestrength by far than thine require.
Magna quidem sacris quae dat fortuna libellis
Victrix fortunae sapientia. Di • imus autem
Hos quo{que} foelices qui ferre incommoda vitae
Nec jactare jugum vita did • cere mag • stra.
Happy are they that either by books and precepts, or by use and experience attaine unto true wisdome and vertue.
Magna non latitant mala diu.
Great evils cannot be long conceal'd.
Magnates dare parva pudet, dare magna recusant.
Great men are ashamed to give small gifts, and loth to bestow great ones.
Magnum pauperies opprobrium, jubet
Quidvis & facere & pati,
Virtutis{que} viam deserit arduae.
The great reproach of poverty to shun,
Into enormityes makes some to run.
— Majore domùs gemitu, majore tumultu
Planguntur nummi, quam funera; nemo dolorem
Fingit in hoc casu.—
For loss of money men more, deeply grone.
Than when their nearest friends are dead & gone;
In that case none do strain tears forth to get,
Nor make a shew of grief that's counterseit.
— Major famae sitis est, quàm
Virtutis; quis enim virtutem amplectitur ipsam,
Praemia si tollas?
Men seek more after honour gay,
Than vertue; for but take away
Vertue's reward, who, who, alas
Does vertue for it self embrace?
Majus ab exequijs nomen in ora venit.
Commonly men are more praised after their death then before.
Major in exiguo regnavit corpore virtus.
A little body often does
A great soul and much worth enclose.
— Magis illa juvant, quae pluris emuntur.
Far fetcht and dear bought is good for Ladies.
Majorum primus quisquis fuit ille tuorum,
Aut pastor fuit, aut illud quod dicere nolo.
Of all thy ancestors, from whom
Thy splendor as thou think'st, doth come;
The first a shepherd was, or that
Which worse is, but I wo'nt say what.
Malo pater tibi sit Thersites, dummodo tu sis
Aeacidae similis, Vulcania{que} arma capessas,
Quam te Thersitae similem producat Achilles.
I had much rather thou should'st have the vile
And soul Thersites for thy Father, while
Thou'rt like Achilles in endowments; then
That thou being base should'st spring from best of men
Male imperatur cum regit vulgus duces.
Things are like to be ill managed, when subjects rule their Princes.
— Manifesta phrenesis,
Ʋt locuples moriaris, egenti vivere fato.
It is plain madness for a man to live like a beggar, that he may dye rich.
—Mala dum crescunt, crescit cautela malorum.
Wit is never good till bought.
Maxima debetur puero reverentia; si quid Turpe paras.
Men should take great heed that they do not any thing unseemly before youth.
Maxima quae{que} domus servis est plena superbis.
Great mens houses are full of proud servants.
Maxima enim morum semper patientia virtus.
Of morall vertues patience is the greatest.
Me miserum, quod amor non est medicabilis herbis.
Love sickness is not to be cured by medicinall applications.
Me tamen urit amor, quis enim modus adsit amori •
Love knowes no measure.
Me quo{que} debilitat series immensa laborum.
Ante meum tempus cogor & esse senex.
Labour and sorrow make men old before their time.
—Melius nil coelibe vitâ.
A single life is best.
—Mentem nil expleverit unquam,
Aetherei cum sit Numinis ipsa capax.
Man's heaven-born soul will not be fill'd,
With all this world to it can yield.
Membra reformidant mollem quo{que} saucia tactum Vana{que} sollicitis incitat umbra metum.
A little touch hurts a sore place, and timerous persons are affrighted at their own shadow.
Membra levant baculis tardi{que} senilibus annis.
Old men are fain to bear up themselves with their staves.
—Metit Orcus
Grandia cum parvis non exorabilis auro.
Inexorably Death's impartial
Mowing down every where both great a small.
Metirise quem{que} suo modulo & pede verum est.
What fits us best, is best; tis good and meet,
To make our shoes according to our seet.
Militat omnis amans, & habet sua castra Cupido.
Each lover is a soldier, nor
Doth Cupid want his tents of war.
Mille modis lethi miseros mors una fatigat.
Though death be one, yet has't a thousand wayes
Whereby that cruel pursivant as slayes.
Millia frumenti tua triverit area centum,
Non tuus hoc capiet venter plus quam meus.—
Though greater store's within thy barns contain'd
My nature is as well as thine maintain'd.
Millibus è tantis vix duo ad astra volant.
'Mongst very many thousands't will be well,
If a tenth part attain in heaven to dwell.
Mille modis morimur miseri sed nascimur uno.
We come into the world one way, but go out many.
Militiae species amor est, discedite segnes.
The name of warfare some on love bestow,
Then hence depart you that are dull and flow.
Mille talenta rotundentur, totidem altera porro:
Tertia succedant, & quae pars quadrat acervum.
Heap up a thousand talents, then one more:
Add a third thousand, and then make 'um four.
—Minuit praesentia formam.
The lion is not so fierce as he is painted.
—Minuit praesentia famam.
Persons and things when present seem not so admirable, as they were reported to be.
—Meritis expendite causam.
Weigh and judge of the cause by the desert.
Miramur perijsse homines, monumenta fatiscunt;
Mors etiam saxis neminibus{que} venit.
It is no wonder that men turn to clay,
When monuments and rocks themselves decay.
— Miranda canunt sed non credenda Poetae.
The Poets in their fictions do
Write things that are more strange than true.
Miraris cum tu argento post omnia ponas;
Si nemo praestet, quem non merearis, amnem.
Admire not that thou art belov'd of none,
Who before all preserrest wealth alone.
Misce stultitiam consilijs brevem,
Dulce est desipere in loco.
Short solly mix with counsells best,
'Tis sweet sometimes to be in jest.
Mista senum ac juvenum densantur funera, nullum
Saeva caput Proserpina sugit.
In death both young and old by heaps do joyn,

Miserrimum est timere cum speres nihil.
It is very sad to be in fear, where nothing is to be hoped for.
— Miserum est alienae incumbere famae.
It is a miserable thing to rely upon another's credit
—Misera est magni custodia census
A great estate hath great trouble.
Mitiùs ille perit subitá qui mergitur undâ.
If we must perish, it is some comfort not to be kept long in pain.
Mitiùs ista seres, aliorum respice casus.
Look upon others wo and pain,
You then may well your grief restrain.
Mitte arcana Dei, caelum{que} inquirere quid sit.
Meddle not with that which God hath kept secret.
Mobilis & varia est fermè natura malorum.
It is the nature of evill men to be sickle and unconstant.
Mobile tempus abit, mora nulla fugacibus annis.
Time swistly posts away
And will for no man stay.
Mobile mutatur semper cum principe vulgus.

Momento aut cita mors venit, aut victoria laeta.
In war, either a speedy death or happy victory comes in a moment.
—Morantur
Pauci ridiculum & fugientem ex urbe pudorem.
Scorn'd modesty is flying hence away,
Whom few (alas) do seek to stop or stay.
Moribus & formâ conciliandus amor.
Good behaviour and beauty procure love,
Mors & fugacem persequitur virum:
Nec parcit imbellis juventae
Poplitibus, timido{que} tergo.
Death the swist flying man pursues
With ready steps; nor doth he use
To spare from unavoided wrack,
Youths supple hams or fearfull back.
Mollis enim in vacuo pectore regnat amor.
Love reigns in a slothfull brest.
—Mollissima corda
Humano generi dare se natura fatetur,
Cum lachrymas dedit.
Nature did not intend, when tears it gave,
That men such cruel slinty hearts should have.
— Monstrat tolerare labores
Non jubet.—
A good commander will say come, not go.
Mopso Nisa datur; quid non speremus amantes?
Hope well and have well.
—Mors sola fatetur
Quantula sunt hominum corpuscula.—
What Pigmy things we are
Death plainly doth declare.
Morbida sola pecus infreit omne pecus.
One scabbed sheep infects the whole slock.
—Mors sceptra ligonibus aequat.
The awfull scepter is by bold death made,
(That leveller) just equall with the spade.
Morte carent animae, semper{que} priore relictà
Sede, novis domibus vivunt, habit ant{que} receptae.
Mans soul is immortall.
Mortalis Dioûm auxilium desiderat omnis.
Every man needs Gods help.
Multa cadunt inter calicem suprema{que} labra.
Many things happen between the cup and the lip.
Multorum manibus grande levatur opus.
Many hands make light work.
—Multi Committunt eadem diverso crimina sato.
The same crimes in severall men have a very different fate and issue.
—Motos praestat componere sluctus.
It is the best way to be quiet.
Mors est peccati merces, & janua vitae.
Death is the wages of sin, and the gate of life.
Mors hominum foelix, quae se nec dulcibus annis Inserit.—
Death is then most unwelcome, when it comes upon us in the years of our pleasure and prosperity.
—Mors optima tunc est Cum petitur, vitae{que} piget, cum funus amatur.
Death is then most welcome, when it is wished for and desired.
Mors rapuit juvenes, sustulit illa senes.
Death takes away young as well as old.
Multa senem circumveniunt incommoda: vel quod
Quaerit, & inventis miser abstinet, ac timet uti
Vel quod res omnes timidè gelidè{que} ministrat.
The old man many evills do girt round;
Either because he seeks, and having found,
Doth wretchedly the use of things forbear,
Or does all business coldly and with fear.
Mulia renascentur quae jam cecidere, cadent{que}
Quae nunc sunt in honore.—
Things now quite antiquated, may
Revive and come again in play:
And those which are admired now,
In time will out of sashion grow.
Multa dies, varius{que} labor mutabilis aevi
Rettulit in melius,—
Things have grown from worse to better in time.
Multa tulit, fecit{que} puer sudavit & alsit.
A boy does much and suffers ills,
He sweats and then again he chills
Multos caecus amor cogit secreta fateri.
Love compels men to disclose many secrets.
Multi ad farum venere suum dum fata timent.
Mischiefs and evils sometimes come with a fear.
Multum in amore sides, multum constantia prodest.
Faith and constancy avail much in love.
Multa dies, & multa litura coerceat, at{que}
Perfectum decies carmen castiget ad unguem.
Hast thou thy verse composed? then
Blot out, and mend, and blot agen,
And mend it ten times over, till
It be exact unto thy will.
Multorum disce exemplo quae facta sequaris,
Quae fugias; vita est nobis aliena magislia.
Learn by other mens examples both what to do, and what to avoid.
Multa fidem promissa levant, ubi plenius aequo
Laudat venales qui vult extrudere merces.
The more men do in promises abound,
The less we do believe; for it is found,

They make as though it were beyond compare.
Multa ferunt anni venientes commoda secum,
Multa recedentes adimunt.
Youthfull years have many advantages, which declining years have not.
Multi sunt mensae, pauci veritatis amici.
There are more Parasites every where than plain dealers.
Multiplici vigilans prudentia surgit ab usu.
Wisdome proceeds from much experience.
—Multi multa loquuntur.
Some say one thing and some another.
—Mulier saevissima tunc est
Cum stimulos odio pudor admovet. —
Then women merciless we find,
When shame is to their hatred joyn'd.
Multa petentibus desunt multa.
A covetous mind is alwayes in want.
Multa loquor, quidvis nummis praesentibus opta
Et veniet. —
He that hath money may have any thing.
Munditiae placeant, careant rubigine dentes.
Delight in neatness and cleanliness.
—Mundi pars maxima nigros
Tendit ad infe • ni manes, ubi luctus & irae.
The greatest part of men do post to hell,
Where dismal torments and deep sorrows dwell.
Munera, crede mihi, placant homines{que} Deos{que}
Placatur donis Jupiter ipse datis.
Gifts prevail wherever they come.
Munus & officium, nil scribeus ipse, docebo.
Though I do little my self, yet will I instruct others what to do.
Multa etenim multam retinet sapientia curam,
Crescit & ipsa sitis cum cognitione sciendi.
Much wisdome hath much care, and the more a man knows, the more he desires to know.
— Mutato nomine, de te Fabula narratur.—
Thou art the man, to whom the sable may be applyed.
Namtua res agitur, paries cum proximus ardet.
When your neighbours house is on fire, beware of your own.
— Nam quis
Peccandi finem posuit sibi, quando recepit
Ejectum semel attrit de fronte ruborem?
Who bounds his vices? when did banish't grace
Return, where it was wip'd out of the face?
Nam ne{que} divitibus contingunt gaudia solis.
Comfort and content of mind
Are not to the rich confin'd.
Nam quicun{que} senex, sensus puerilis in illo est.
Old men begin to grow childish again.
Nam scelus intra se tacitum qui cogit at ullum,
Facti crimen habet: cedo si conata peregit?
Th'intent of sin is taken for the act:
What is it then if one commit the fact:
Nam nulli tacuisse nocet, nocet esse locutum.
Silence seldome hurteth any,
Speech hath prejudiced many.
Nam dolor & morbus lethi fabricator uter{que} est.
Sorrow will shorten a mans life as well as Diseases.
Nam{que} solent, primo quae sunt neglecta, nocere.
Matters at first neglected, may
That negligence with sorrow pay.
Nam genus, & proavos, & quae non secimus ipsi,
Vix ea nostra voco.
Heroick acts which made my Fathers shine,
And what my self did not, I call not mine.
Nam quid longa dies homini nisi longa dolorum Colluvies?
What is a long life, but even a continued sink of sorrows?
Nam vitijs nemo sine nascitur; optimus ille est Qui minimis urgetur.
They are unborn, who have no sin at all;
He's a good man, whose faults are few and small.
Nascentes morimur, sinis{que} ab origine pendet.
We are as it were dying, as soon as we come into the world.
Nascimur arbitrio superûm, mori mur{que}, nec ulli Fas sperare hominum quicquam sine numine Divun
We're born, and dye, and all things else beside
According to Gods will to us betide.
Nate Deâ, quo fata trahunt, retrahunt{que} sequamu •
Let us comport our selves to God's soveraign disposall of us.
Natur am expellas furcâ licet, us{que} recurret.

It will return, it's force you cannot quell.
Naturae sequitur semina quis{que} suae.
Every one followes the inclinations of his nature.
Navita de ventis, de tauris narrat arator.
Every one to his trade.
Ne pudeat, quae nescieris, te velle doceri.
Be not ashamed to be taught what you are ignorant of.
Nec poterit celare suas, nec vincere curas Faemina
The weaker sex unable are
To conquer or conceal their care.
— Nec studium sine divite venâ Nec rude quid prosit video ingenium. —
Art with a vein of wit does very well,
What good they'l do apart, I cannot tell.
— Nec unquam.
Sanguine causidici maduerunt rostra pusilli.
Dull sorry pleaders may well merit shame,
None e're were spighted but brave men of same.
Nec mullum cupias cùm sit tibi gobio tantum
In loculis, quis enim te, deficiente crumenâ
Et crescente gulâ, manet exitus?

Nec facile est aequâ commoda mente pati.
It's hard to bear prosperity in a right manner.

Curat reponi deterioribus.

Mista ferè duris utilis herba rubis.
So very bad and barren there's no field,
But mixt with brambles usefull herbs may yield.
Nec minor est virtus, quam quaerere, parta tueri:
Casus inest illic, hoc erit artis opus.
Well keeping and husbanding what's gotten, deserveth praise as well as getting.
Nec quae praeterijt, rursum revocabitur undd,
Nec quae praeterijt hora redire potest.
The water that's run by, none can recall;
And th'hour that's past is gone for good and all.
Nec quisquam melior medicus quam fidus amicus.
There is no Physician comparable to a faithfull friend.
Nec semper feriet quodcun{que} minabitur arcus.
We must not expect that the arrow should always hit the mark.
Nec tellus eadem parit omnia; vitibus illa
C •• venit, haec olei, hic benè farra virent.
Every ground doth most naturally bear its own peculiar fruit.
Nec retinent patulae commissa fideliter aures.
The ears of some so open are,
That what they hear they must declare.
Nec semper violae, nec semper lilia florent;
Et riget amissa spina relicta rosâ.
Flowers do not alwayes florish: every thing hath its season.
Nec tibi quid liceat, sed quid fecisse decebit
Succurrct, mentem{que} domet respectus honesti.
Consider not only what is lawfull, but what may be expedient and comely.
Nec tibi regnandi veniat tam dira cupido.
Be not over-ambitious of great dignity and dominion.
Nec laudare satis dignas{que} rependere grates
Sufficiam, referent Superi. —
I hope God will reward your kindness, it is not in my power to do it.
Nec vero terrae serre omnes omnia possunt.
Every sort of ground will not bring forth every sort of fruit.
Nec tua laudabis studia, aut aliena reprendes.
It becomes not to applaud what's our own, nor to disparage what's anothers.
Nec V • neris, nec tu vini capiaris amore,
Ʋno nam{que} modo vina Venus{que} nocent.
Take heed of loving Venery or wine,
The same way to your ruine both combine.
Nec quicquam populo bibulas donaveris aures.
Do not listen after the peoples applanses.
Neglectis urenda filix innascitur agris.
Fern good for nothing but the fire,
Will the neglected field attire.
Nemo adeo ferus est, qui non mitescere possit,
Si modo culturae patientem praebeat aurem.
None is so savage, but he may grow mild
If unto good instruction he will yield.
Nemo satis credit tantum delinquere, quantum
Permittas, adeo indulgent sibi latiùs ipsi.
In sin, if you give men an inch, they will take an ell.
Nemo silens placuit, multi brevitate loquendi.
He that would please must not talk overmuch nor be altogether silent.
Nemo repentè fuit turpissimus.
None comes to the height of sin on a suddain, but by degrees.
Nemo confidat nimiùm secundis,
Nemo desperet meliora lapsis.
Let none trust too much to prosperity, nor despair in adversity.
Ne tibi quid desit, quaesitis utere parcè.
Be a good husband of your estate, that you may not want.
— Nemo quam sibi sortem
Seu ratio dederit, seu sors objecerit, illà
Contentus vivit.
Few live content with their condition.
Nempe coquus domini debet habere gulam.
The Cook should know what will please his Master's palate.
Nempe inamarescunt epulae sine fine petitae.
By constant feasting men at last
Less savour in their dainties tast.
— Nec lex est justior ulla Quàm necis artisices arte perire suà.
Harm watch, harm catch.
Nescit homo certi incertissima classica lethi.
Nothing is so certain as death, and nothing so uncertain as the time when.
— Ne{que} ulla est
Aut magno aut parvo lethi fuga.—
Neither great nor small can by any means avoid death.
Ne dubites, cùm magna petas, impendere parva.
Do not lose an hog for a half-penny-worth of tarr.
Nescia mens hominum fati, sortis{que} futurae,
Et servare modum rebus sublata secundis.
Men in their prosp'rous state are proud and high
Ignorant of their future destiny.
Nescio quà natale solum dulcedine cunctos
Ducit, & immemores non sinit esse sui.
Unto their native country we do find,
All men with strange and ardent love inclin'd.
Nil equidem durare diu sub imagine eadem
Crediderim.
Nothing here below continues long in the same state.
Nil homine in terrâ spirat miserum magis.—
No creature in the whole world is liable to so many miseries as man.
—Nihil est quod credere de se
Non audet, quum laudatur Dijs aequa potestas.
That man in his own pride must needs rise high
Whom men with flatt'ring titles deifie.
— Nil non mortale tenemus,
Pectoris exceptis ingenij{que} bonis.
With all we have we soon may part,
Except the goods of mind and heart.
— Nescit vox mista reverti.
Words once spoken cannot possibly be recalled.
Nil adeo fortuna gravis miser abile fecit,
Ʋt minuant nullâ gaudia parte malum.
There is no estate so afflictive, but there is some comfort mixt with it.
Nil habet infelix paupertas durius in se
Quàm quod ridiculos homines facit. —
Nothing makes poverty more grievous, then
That it contemptible doth render men.
Nil dictu foedum visu{que} haec limina tangat,
Intra quae puer est.
Nothing di • -honest or unseemly should be spoken or done before boyes.
Nil ita sublime est, supra{que} pericula tendit,
Non sit ut inferius, suppositum{que} Deo.
None is so high, and from all danger free,
But must to God's great power subject be.
Nil nisi turpe juvat, curae est sua cui{que} voluptas,
Haec quo{que} ab alterius grata dolore venit.
Nothing doth please some men but what is bad;
Though sweet and lawfull pleasure may be had,
It doth not please: that, that alone they prize,
Which from another's dammage doth arise.
Nil nocet admisso subdere calcar equo.
Although the horse be generous and free,
A little spurring may not hurtfull be.
Nil prodest quod non laedere possit idem.
Persons and things that do prosit us may also harm us.
Nil nisi quod prodest charum est, en detrahe menti
Spem fructus avidae, nemo petendus crit.
Some love none but from whom gain doth acrue,
The hope of that once gone, they'l bid adien.
Nimirum sapere est abjectis uttle nugis.
Et tempestivum pueris concedere ludum.
Men should grow wise, and leave mean toyes,
A proper sport for game some boyes.
Nitimur in vetitum semper, cupimus{que} negata;
Sic interdictis imminet aeger aquis.
What is forbidden us we desire the more.
Nocte Die{que} tuum gestas in pectore testem.
Thou alwayes carriest a witness in thine own bosome.
Non est ad astra mollis è terris via.
It is no easie matter to get to heaven.
Non luget quisquis laudari, Gellia, quaerit.
Their sorrow is not true but vain,
Who praise thereby seek to obtain.
— Non, si quid turbida Roma
Elevet, accedas: examenve improbum in illâ
Castiges trutinà, nec te quaesiveris extra.
Do not judge of thy self by others opinions of thee.
Non possidentem multa vocaveris
Reciè beatum.
None, that weighs things rightly can
Call the rich the blessed man.
Nemo potentes aggredi tutus potest.
None can with safety encounter or oppose the mighty.
Non enim gazae, ne{que} consularis
Summovet lictor miseros tumultus
Mentis, & runas Lqueata circum Tecta volantes.
It is not wealth nor armed troops,
Can tumults of the mind remove,
And cares, which about fretted roofs
Hover above.
Non sollicitae possunt curae
Mutare rati stamina fusi.
All our cares can by no means change Divine determinations.
Non abolet prorsus mors facta illustria, virtus
Vivit apud superos, & habet sua praemia. mdash;
Brave deeds and spotless vertue have
Rewards, that do outlive the grave.
Non benè conveniunt, nec in unâ sede morantur
Majestas & amor.—
Majesty and love seldome kindly meet together.
Non cui vis homini contingit adire Corinthum.
