Every man is not born with a silver-spoon in his mouth.
Non benè Coelestes impia dextra colit.
Ungodly hands unseemly are
To be lift up to God in prayer.
Non est ad Musas currere lata via.
It is no easie matter to become learned.
Non est, crede mihi, sapientis dicere vivam,
Sera nimis vita est crastina, vive hodie.
It is no wisemans property
(Believe me) to procrastinate.
To morrow thou'lt amend; but why
Not now day? to morrow's late.
Non ego ventosae plebis suffragia venor.
I do not hunt after the windy applause of the unconstant vulgar.
Non cadem ratio est curare & cernere morbos;
Sensus inest cunctis, tollitur arte malum.
It is much more easie to discover a disease or evill than to remove it.
Non Deus, ut perhibent Amor est; sed amaror & error.
Love is no God, as Poets feign
But bitterness and error vain.
Nomen amicitiae barbara corda movet,
Friendship hath an insluence even upon barbarians themselves.
Non habet eventus sordida praeda bonos.
Ill gotten goods seldome prosper.
Non est in medico semper relevetur ut aeger.
'Tis past the best Physician's skill
Alwayes to cure the sick at will.
Non habet officium lucifer omnis idem.
Every star hath not the same office.
Non formosus erat, sed erat facundus Ʋllysses,
Et tamen aequoreas torsit amore Deas.
Ʋlysses much in beauty did not shine,
But yet his eloquence was so divine,
As did the Sea-Nymphs unto him incline.
Non domus, & fundus, non aeris acervus & auri,
Aegroto domini deduxit corpore sebres.
Nor house, nor land, nor heaps of glitt'ring ore.
Can unto their sick owner health restore.
Non bove mactato coelestia numina gaudent;
Sed, quae praestanda est & sine teste, fide.
In slaughter'd victims God no pleasure hath,
But in a reall and unfeigned Faith.
Non juvat ex facili lecta corona jugo.
That wreath of honour doth not please
Ingenuous minds, which comes with ease.
Non dulcem è quovis apis ingeniosa liquorem
Flore, sed è lecto germine mella legit.
The Bee from every flower doth not take
Her honey, but a prudent choice doth make.
Nonne mori satiùs, vitae quam ferre pudorem?
It is better to dye, than to live in ignominy.
Non fuit in uno condita Roma die.
Rome was not built on a day.
Non honor est, sed onus, species laesura ferentes;
Si qua voles aptè nubere, nube pari.
That greatness is a burden, not an honour,
Which bringeth disadvantage to the owner;
Therefore if you would fitly wedded be,
Be sure match with your equall in degree.
Non ignara mali miseris succurrere disco.
Those that have been in affliction, know best how to pity the afflicted.
Non holocausta Deus sed corda fdelia quaerit.
God delights not in burnt offerings, but in an honest and faithfull heart.
Non ideo debet pelago se credere, si qua
Audet in exiguo ludere cymba lacu.
Because the boat i'th pond doth safely ride,
It must not lanch into the ocean wide.
Non labor est populis assuescere legibus istis,
Quas Reges servare vident.—
To keep good laws men easily are brought,
The same being by the Kings example taught.
Non omnes arbusta juvant, humiles{que} myricae.
Mean things please not all.
Non bene cum socijs regna Venus{que} manent,
The throne and marriage-bed can brook no partners.
Non opibus mentes hominum curae{que} levantur.
Riches do not ease mens minds, nor lessen their cares.
Non propter vitam faciunt patrimonia quidam,
Sed vitio caeci propter patrimonia vivunt.
Some seek not wealth, life to maintain:
But rather live estates to gain
Non solum taurus ferit uncis cornibus hostem,
Verum etiam instanti laesa repugnat ovis.
Not only Bulls enraged push, but when
Provok'd, the harmless sheep will turn agen.
Non sit in arcanis mulier tibi conscia rebus.
Trust not women with your secrets.
Nos quo{que} floruimus, sed slos fuit ille cadueus.
Man in his best estate is but a fading flower.
Nos nameri sumus, & sruges consumere nati.
A number we do make up, and
Are born to eat the fat o'th'land.
Nos miscri quibus una dies suprema, quis aevi
Exitus incertum, quibus instet fulmen ab astris.
Man's wofull state is such, he knows one day
Must be his last, but which there's none can say.
Nos ubi decidimus
Quo pius Aenaeas, quo Tullus dives, & Ancus
Pulvis & umbra sumus.
Hither return again, when dead, none must;
We shall be nothing but a shade and dust.
— Nobilitas sola est at{que} unica virtus.
Vertue may rightly stiled be
The only true nobility.
Non praematuri cineres, nec funus acerbum
Luxuriae, sed morte magis metuenda senectus.
Untimely funerals gluttons cannot have,
Old age is more their terrour than the grave.
Noscitur ex socio qui non dignoscitur ex se.
One may know what a man is by the company that he usually keeps.
Nosse volunt omnes, mercedem solvere nemo.
All men would have knowledge but they would not pay for't.
Nostra brevis velox{que} aetas, & plena laborum.
Man's age is short and swift and full of toil.
Nocte latent mendae, vitio{que} ignoscitur omni,
Hora{que} formosam quamlibet illa facit.
Blemishes are not seen by night: in the dark Joan is as good as my Lady.
Noctes at{que} dies patet atri janua Ditis.
Hell's gate stands wide open night and day.
Nox, & amor, vinum{que} nihil moderabile suadent.
These three ill counsellors, night, love, and wine,
Do men to nothing moderate incline.
Nube solet pulsà candidus ire dies.
Oft threatning clouds do break away,
And it becomes a pleasant day.
Novistine locum potiorem rure beato?
Est ubi plus tepeant hyemes, ubi gratior aura Leniat & rabiem canis? —
There is no place for air so pleasant as the countrey, whether in winter or summer.
Nullus ad amissas ibit amicus opes.
When we are in adversity our friends do often forsake us.
Nulla dies adeo est australibus humida nimbis,
Non intermissis ut fluat imber aquis
Rain all day long most rarely does so fall,
As intermission to have none at all.
Nil ego contulerim jucundo sanus amico.
Nothing is to be compared with a pleasant friend
— Nos virtutes ipsas invertimus, at{que}
Sincerum cupimus vas incrustare.—
Too often good mens vertues we,
By judgment pass'd censoriously,
Turn into vices; and would fain
Give unto vessels pure, some stain.
Nulla autem effigies, nulli commissa metallo
Forma Dei, mentes habitare & pectora gaudet.
It's vain Christs image though in Gold to make;
He loves our hearts for's dwelling place to take.
Nulla fides unquam miseros elegit amicos.
None ever chose a man in misery for his friend.
Nulla vis major pietate verâ est.
Nothing is of greater force than true godliness.
Nulla sors longa est, dolor & voluptas Invicem cedunt, brevior voluptas.
No state lasts long, grief and joy do
Take turns, for still the one gives way
To t'other, but yet of the two,
It's joy that makes the shorter stay.
Nullite facias nimis sodalem,
Gaudebis miaus, & minus dolebis.
Be not with any over intimate,
Your joy and grief will be more moderate.
Nullius addictus juravi in verba magistri.
I pin my Faith upon no mans sleeve.
Nullus in inferno est atheos, ante fuit.
In the world there are atheists, in hell there are none.
Nulla salus bello, pacem te poscimus omnes.
In war there's no safety, all men desire peace.
Nulla fides piet as{que} viris, qui castra sequuntur.
There's little faith or honesty in Soldiers.
Nulla fides regni socijs, omnis{que} potestas Impatiens consortis erit.—
Kings cannot bear partners.
Nulla fere causa est, in quâ non foemina litem
Moverit.—
There's scarce any quarrel but a woman is at one end of it.
Nulla suo res est si sit data tempore vilis.
Nothing is despicable if given in a right season.
Nullum numen abest si sit prudentia. —
If we act wisely, God will not be wanting to us.
Nullus enim magni sceleris labor. —
Great wickedness requires little labour.
Nulla placere diu, nec vivere carmina possunt,
Quae scribuntur aquae potoribus.
Drinkers of water seldom poems write,
That last, or yield the reader long delight.
Nullum cum victis certamen & aethere cassis.
Tis foolish with the vanquished
Much to contest, or with the dead.
Nunc hederae sine honore jacent, operata{que} doctis
Cura vigil musis nomen inertis habet.
Learning and learned men do now adayes
Fall short (alas) of their deserved praise.
— Nunc aurum & purpura curis
Exercent homines.—
Riches and honour produce cares.
Nunquam aliud natura, aliud sapientia dicit
Nature and wisdome do not contradict each other.
Nunquam bella bonis, nunquam certamina desunt,
Et cum quo certet menspia semper habet.
A Godly man shall be sure not to want either inward or outward enemies.
Nunquam placidam sceptra quietem
Certum{que} sui tenuere diem.
Scepters cause wakefull care,
And most uncertain are.
Nunquam stygias fertur ad undas Inclyta virtus.
Vertue is immortal.
Nusquam tuta fides. —
Trust men no further than you can throw them.
Nutritur vento, vento restinguitur ignis;
Lenis alit flammas, grandior aura necat.
The fire's increased by the wind,
And by it quenched too we find;
Small blasts do much augment the flame,
But boystrous ones suppress the same.
O fortuna potens quam variabilis,
Tantum juris atrox quae tibi vendicas,
Evertis{que} bonos, eligis improbos!
How doth unconstant fortune overthrow the good, and favour the wicked?
O quantum bonum est
Obstare nulli carpere securas dapes!
O how good is it to live in peace without opposition to any?
O quam miserum est nescire mori!
How sad is it not to know how to dye?
O si paveant pectora Ditum,
Quantos intus sublimis agit
Fortuna metus?
With how great fears doth inconstant fortune vex the hearts of rich men?
O funestus multis, populi
Dirus{que} favor, qui cum flatu
Vela secundo ratis implevit,
Vexit{que} procul, languidus idem
Deserit altos s • vo{que} mari.
The favour of the people is deceitfull and pernitious, for when it hath lifted a man up, it afterwards failes him when he hath most need of it.
O cives. cives, quaerenda pecunia primum,
Virtus post nummos.
The most say, let us first get money, and then think of being vertuous.
O fortunatos nimium sua si bona n • rint
Agricolas! —
How happy a life might countreymen live if they did but know their own advantages?
O miseras hominum mentes! ô pectora caeca!
Qualibus in tenebris vitae, quantis{que} periclis
Degimus?—
In what darkness and danger doth poor ignorant man live?
O curas hominum! ò quantum est in rebus inane!
What fruitless cares do mortals minds still know,
What vanity's in all things here below?
O quam turpe viro muliebri incedere cultu!
It is shamefull for a man to be attired like a woman.
O formose puer, nimium necrede colori.
Trust not too much to beauty.
O passi graviora, dabit Deus his quo{que} finem.
Worse troubles you have born, & God may please
E're long likewise to put an end to these.
O Superi! quantum mortalia pectora caecae Noctis habent?
Alas how ignorant is man?
O quanta exempli generoso in principe vis est!
Of how great force is the example of a noble Prince?
— O vitae tuta facultas
Pauperis, angusti{que} laris! ò munera nondum
Intellecta Deum!
A mean condition hath such safety and priviledges as few do understand.
O mihi praeteritos referat si Jupiter annos.
Oh that I could recover time past!
— Oh prodiga rerum
Luxuries, nunquam parvo contenta paratu!
A little will not satisfie
Luxurious prodigality.
Obsequium tigres{que} domat, tumidos{que} leones.
Yielding tames even the fierce lions and tygers,
Obsequio quoniam dulces retinentur amici.
Friendship is preserved by fair compliancy.
— Obest quo{que} gloria multis.
Great advancement hath hurt many a man.
O curvae in terras animae, & coelestium inanes!
O Souls that grovel in the dust and mire,
And do to nothing heavenly aspire!
Obsequio tranantur aquae, nec vincere possis
Flumina, si contra quam rapit unda nates.
By yielding to the stream we quickly gain,
What otherwise we labour for in vain.
Occidit miseros crambe repetita magistros.
Poor Schoolmasters the twice boil'd lettuce kills,
Which they must oft repeat against their wills.
Occurrunt animo pereundi mille figurae.
There are a thousand wayes to dye.
Oderunt hilarem tristes, tristem{que} jocosi.
Merry men and melancholy do not like one anothers company.
Oderunt peccare boni virtutis amore;
Good men from vice for love of vertue run
Oderunt peccare mali formidine poenae.
But fear alone makes bad men vice to shun.
Odimus accipitrem quia vivit semper in armis,
Et pavidum solitos in pecus ire lupos.
We hate both hawks and wolves, because that they
Are wont upon the innocent to prey.
Odimus immodicos (experto credite) fastus.
Unmeasurable pride begets hatred.
Odi, nec possum cupiens non esse quod odi.
What I hate, that do I.
Omne solum forti patria est, ut piscibus aequor.
Every land to a valiant man is as it were his own countrey.
Omnes una manet nox
Et calcanda semel via lethi.
We must all dye.
Omnia perversas possunt corrumpere mentes.
Every thing makes a bad heart worse.
Omnia sunt hominum tenui pendentia filo.
All humane things hang upon a very slender thread.
Omne bonum praesens minus est, sperata videntur Magna.
The good appears but small, which now we have.
But what we long for to us seems most brave.
Omnem crede diem tibi diluxisse supremum.
Think every day to be your last day.
Omnibus esse lupos licet in regione luporum.
That seems imitable which is universally practised were we live.
Omnia cum videat, nulli Deus ipse videtur.
God sees all but is seen of none.
Omnia sub leges mors vocat atra suas.
All must dye.
Omnia mors aufert, restituit{que} nihil.
Death's greedy mouth still craving is for more,
Devouring all, but nothing will restore.
Omnia vincit amor & nos cedamus amori.
Nothing love's mighty power withstands,
Let us then yield to its commands.
Omne aliud vitium mox ferrea protulit aetai.
All wicked practices and sin
Did with the iron age come in.
Omne animi vitium tantò conspectius in se
Crimen habet, quantò mujor qui peccat habetur.
The greater he that sinneth is in place,
The more his crimes conspic'ous are and base.
Omnia sunt magnis factu proclivia Divis.
All things are easie to God.
Omnia despera prudenter, & omnia spera Fortiter.
There's nothing but we should fear it prudently, and nothing but what we should hope for couragiously.
Omne in praecipiti vitium stetit. —
Vice is at its height.
Omnia quae sensu volvuntur vota diurno
Tempore noctur no reddit amica quies.
What things by day we chiefly do purspe,
The same in nightly dreams we oft review.
Omnia deficiunt, animus tamenomnia vincit.
Courage masters the greatest difficulties.
Omnis in Ascanio chari stat cura parentis
All the care of loving parents is for their dear children.
Omnia praetereunt praeter amare Deum.
All things decay but grace alone.
Omnis enim debet sine vano nuncius esse.
What signifie news if they are not true?
Omnia non pariter rerum sunt omnibus apta.
All things are not fit for all.
Omnia tempus edax depascitur omnia carpit.
Time devours and destroyes all things.
Omnia de nihilo qui fecit, is omnia solus:
Quod Deus ex nihilo fecit, id omne nihil.
God is all, who of nothing did make all;
And what God made of nothing, nothing call.
Omnibus invisa est stolidae jactantia mentis.
Every one dislikes a boaster.
Omnia cum pereant, est virtus sola perennis.
Vertue alone is immortall, all things else perish.
Omnibus hoc vitium est cantoribus, inter amicos
Ʋt nunquam inducant animum cantare rogati;
Injussi nunquam desistant.—
Singers when of their friends requested, still
Say nay, but undesir'd your cars they'l fill
With endless tunes.
Omnia post obitum sing it majora vetustas.
Posterity alwayes magnifies things past and gone.
— Omnia Romae
Cum pretio.—
Every thing at Rome for the penny.
Omnia solliciti sunt loca plena metûs.
Nor the King's court, nor beggars cottage are
Exempt from irksome and perplexing fear.
Omnis commoditas sua fert incommoda secum.
There's no convenience without an inconvenience.
Omnibus adde modum, modus est pulcherrima virt ••
Moderation is an excellent vertue.
Omne tulit punctum qui miscuit utile dulcit.
Men in their suffrages must needs unite
For him that mingleth profit with delight.
Omnibus in rebus medium laudare solemus.
Moderation is laudable.
Omnil us invideas, livide, nemo tibi.
Miserable wretch art thou, who enviest every man, and no body thee.
— Obrepit non intellecta senectus.
Old age creeps upon us before we are aware.
Omne nocet nimium, mediocriter omne gerendum,
Too much of one thing is good for nothing.
Omnia sunt ingrata, nihil fecisse benignè est.
When all that we do is unacceptable, it is best to do nothing.
— Opes sceler ati nempe repostae
In domini exitium.—
Riches are sometimes laid up for the hurt of their owners.
Opprime dum nova sunt subiti mala semina morbi Nam mora dat vires.
Resist diseases at first, for by delay they will get strength.
Optat ephippia bos piger, optat arare caballus.
Quam scit uter{que} libens censebo, exterceat artem.
The Ox would be for th'saddle, th'Horse for plough
Let all (say I) use well the art they know.
Optima quae{que} dies miseries mortalibus aevi
Prima fugit; subeunt morbi, tristis{que} senectus,
Our youthfull and best dayes flee away first, sickness and old age come up in the rear.
Ores, casta legas, jejunes, otia tollas;
Si vis servari corpora casta Deo.
Read what is pure, shun sloth, and pray, and fast;
If that you would your selves keep pure and chast.
Os homini sublime dedit, coelum{que} tueri Jussit. —
Man was made erect, that he might look up to heaven.
Otia si tollas periere Cupidinis arcus.
Shun idleness, and then a fig for Cupid and his darts.
Otia corpus alunt, animus quo{que} pascitur illis.
A moderate cessation from labour refresheth both body and mind.
Orandum est ut sit mens sana in corpore sano.
We should pray that we may have a sound mind in a sound body.
— Ovo prognatus eodem.
A chip of the old block.
Pace augentur opes, minuuntur tempore belli.
Riches by peace increased are,
But less'ned in the time of war.
Pallida mors aequo pulsat pede pauperum tabernas,
Regum{que} turres.
Death knocks as boldly at the door
Of Kings, as at the hurts o'th'poor.
Palma negata macrum, donata reducit opimum.
The Palm deny'd makes the poor man look thin,
The champion's plump when he the prize doth win.
Pars hominum vitijs gaudet constanter, & urget
Propositum. —
Too many rejoyce and obstinately continue in sin.
Parce bonis, & perde malos, propone quibus{que}
Justitiam. —
Rulers should be a terror to evill doers and an encouragement to them that do well, and do justice to all.
Parturient mortes, nascetur ridiculus mus.
Great boast and little roast, or, great cry and little wool.
— Parvae poterunt impellere causae
In scelus.—
A small matter will draw men unto sin.
Parva necat morsu sp • ciosum vipera taurum.
The little viper sometimes may
The larger bull with poyson slay.
〈…〉 exemplo est magur formica laboris.
Patterns of labour we shall never want,
While we behold the small yet painful Ant.
〈…〉 decent. —
Mean things become a mean person.
〈…〉 is curam, nimium{que} severus,
Assidet insano.—
He that to gratify a greedie heir,
And make him rich, is griple and severe,
Enjoying not himself, doth alwayes sit
Hard by a mad man, or one void of wit.
Pascitur in vivis livor, post fata quiescit.
Sly envy doth men living hate,
Once dead, it's malice doth abate.
Passibus ambiguls fortuna volubilis errat,
Et manet in nullo certa tenax{que} loco.
Fortune doth no where certain stay,
But still doth change her fickle way.
— Patitur poenas peccandi sola voluntas.
A will and desire to sin sometimes procures punishment.
— Pauci quos aequus amavit
Jupiter, aut ardens evexit ad aethera virtus.
Those who God's love and favour gain, and do
To heaven get, in number are but few.
— Pauci laeta arva tenemus.
Few get to heaven.
— Pauci dignoscere possunt
Vera bona, at{que} illis multùm diversa remotâ
Erroris nebula.—
Few men can clearly distinguish between good and evill.
Paulùm sepuliae distat inertiae Celata virtus.
Vertue concealed differs but little from dead sloth.
Pauper enim non est cui rerum suppetit usus.
That man is far from poor, who can produce
What e're is necessary for his use.
Paupertatis onus pati enter ferre memento.
Bear the burden of poverty patiently.
pauper eris semper, si pauper es Aemiliane,
Dantur opes nullis nunc nisi divitibus.
If thou art poor, then poor shalt thou remain;
Rich men alone do now rich gifts obtain.
Pauca voluptati debentur, plura saluti.
We owe more to our health than to our pleasure.
Pauperies inimica bonis est moribus.
Poverty is an enemy to good manners.
Paulatim deinde ad Superos Astraea recessit.
By little and little Justice left the Earth.
Patria ubi{que}, bonis, exilium{que} malis.
The good man is in any place at home,
The bad's an exile wheresoe're he come.
Pauper in exilio est nullibi, ubi{que} domi.
The Beggar is never out of his way.
Pax Cererem nutrit, pacis alumna Ceres.
Peace maketh Corn to grow amain,
And so requites the Farmer's pain.
— Pax optima rerum
Quas homini novisse datum, pax una triumphis
Innumeris melior. —
Amongst all good things here below,
Peace is the best that man doth know:
Peace, peace alone is better far
Than multitudes of Triumphs are.
Pax hominum genetrix, pax est custodia rerum.
To men, and wealth, Peace Mother is and Nurse,
Pax aperit juris justitiae{que} forum.
Peace unto Laws and Justice gives free course.
Pectorbus mores tot sunt, quot in orbe figurae.
Tempers of mind as various be,
As outward shapes i'th world we see.
Pejora juvenes sacile praecepta audiunt.
Young men are very prone to listen to bad counsel.
Peccato gravins non reperitur onus.
No burden is more grievous than that of sin.
Pectora dum gaudent, tunc subit arte Venus.
When peoples hearts are over-jolly,
Let them beware of Lust and Folly.
Pellitur è medio sapientia, vi geritur res.
Wisdom aside too many lay,
In their Affairs, Force bears the sway.
Percontatorem fugito, nam garrulus idem est.
Shun such as into thy Affairs do love
Much to enquire, they'l leaking Vessels prove.
Per varios casus, per tot discrimina rerum,
Tendimus in Latium.
Through various hazards, and through dangers great,
We aim unto our wished port to get.
Per varios usus artem experientia fecit.
Much Experience produceth Art.
Perdidit horrendo Trojam Venus improba bello.
'Twas Lust that did of old destroy
By dreadfull Warr the famous Troy.
Perfer, perpetiendo parit patientia palmam.
Hold out, patience will get you the victory.
Perfer, & obdura, dolor hic tibi proderit olim.
Saepe tulit lassis succus amarus opem.
Hold out in patience, this your grief
Profit hereafter may produce;
Oft hath the sick mans best relief
Arisen from a bitter Juice.
Pernicies homini quae maxima? solus homo alter.
A greater enemy man hath none
Unto him, than is man alone
Ploratur lachrymis amissa pecunia veris.
The loss of Money men ne're fail
With truest tears for to bewail.
— Perit omnis in illo
Nobiltas, cujus laus est in origine sola,
That mans Nobility is well-nigh spent,
Whose onely glory is his high descent.
— Pictoribus atque Poetis
Quidlibet audendi semper fuit aequa Potestas.
Painters and Poets have power to feign any thing.
Permittes ipsis expendere Numinibus, quid
Conveniaet nobis, rebus{que} sit utile nostris:
Nam pro jucundis aptissima quae{que} dabunt Dii
Charior est illis homo quam sibi.—
Let God alone to choose what's good
And meet for man, for though he shou'd
See cause things pleasant not to grant,
Yet what's most fit we shall not want:
God loveth man far better, than
He himself either doth, or can.
Plurima virtuti laus est, sed praemia nulla.
Vertue is much praised by many, but rewarded by few.
Pluris opes nunc sunt, quam prisci temporis annis.
Riches are now adayes more admired than formerly they were.
Plur ima discenti semper sapientia crescit.
The more we learn, the more wise we grow.
Plus aliis de te, quam tu tibi credere noli.
Do not believe what others say of you,
Except in your own breast you find it true.
Plus valet humanis viribus ira Dei.
Gods Anger exceeds all mans strength.
Plus vigila, semper ne somno deditus esto.
See that thy self thou watchfull keep,
And be not given to sottish sleep.
— Populus me sibilat, at mihi plaudo
Ipse domi, simulac nummos contemplor in arcâ.
The Miser saith, When e're I walk abroad,
The people hiss me, but I do applaud,
And hugg my self at home, when I behold
My chests brim-full with Silver and with Gold
— Poenam culpa secunda ferat.
The second fault will not be passed by.
Post obitum benefacta manent, aeterna{que} virtus
Non metuit Stygiis ne rapiatur aquis.
Good deeds and vertue never dye,
But doe survive and Death desie.
Praestabat castas humilis fortuna Latinas
Quondam, nec vitiis contingi parva sinebat
Tecta labor, somni{que} breves. —
A mean Estate and mod'rate sleep,
Did chaste the Roman Women keep;
These things of old, and labour hard
Vice out of their small houses barr'd.
Prima peregrinos obscoena pecunia mores
Intulit, & turpi fregerunt saecula luxu
Divitiae molles.—
Money that bawd did first bring in
Strange Fashions and all kind of sin:
To wealth we may it much impute,
That th'age is grown so dissolute.
Principibus placuisse viris haud ultima laus est.
Let him that hath the length o'th' Princes foot,
Enjoy his favour, yea and praise to boor.
Principis est virtus maxima nisse suos.
It is great vertue in a Prince to know his People.
Pingue solum lassat, sed juvat ipse labor.
Labour employ'd on a fat soil
Delighteth, though there's greater toil.
Principis obsta, sero medicina paratur
Cùm mala per longas invaluere moras.
Stop growing Evils while they're in their Spring;
When they've got head, too late you med'eines bring.
Praesemem{que} refert quaelibet herba Deum.
Ev'n every herb shews the power of God.
— Probitas laudatur & alget.
Honesty is praised, but little practised or rewarded.
Pro captu Lectoris habent sua fata libelli.
Books have their Fates according to the capacity and apprehension of the Reader.
Pro telo geritur quicquid suggesserit ira.
Anger will make a weapon of any thing.
Praevisum est levius quod fuit ante malum.
Evils foreseen, afflict the less when they come.
Prodigus & stultus donat quae spernit & odit.
Both Prodigals and Fools are liberall
Of what they hate, or value not at all.
Prodiga non sentit pereúntem foemina censum.
Prodigal Women oft-times spend too fast,
Ne're minding how their husbands stock does wast.
Promissis dives quilibet esse potest.
Any one may be rich in promises.
Pro vitio virtus crimina saepe tulit.
Vertue hath too often been mistaken for vice.
Plus ratio quam vis caeca valere solet.
Reason is wont to prevail more than blind force.
Projicit ampullas & sesquipedalia verba.
He casts away long, lofty, and arrogant words.
Proq, suâ causi quisque disertus erit.
Every one may best be eloquent in his own cause.
Protinus ante meum quicquid dolet exue limen.
Look when thou dost approach near to my door,
Thou lay aside what grieved thee before.
Proximus ille Deo qui scit ratione tacere.
He is a truly wise man that knows when to keep silence, and when to speak.
Prospera non inslent animum, nec aspera frangam.
Let not Prosperity pusse thee up, nor Adversity dismay thee.
Proximus à tectis ignis defenditur aegrè.
Flames hardly are kept off, when they
On the next neighbours house do prey.
Prudens futuri temporis exitum
Ridet{que} si mortalis ultra
Fas trepidat.
God is most wise in hiding from
Man's knowledge that which is to come:
Therefore he smileth as it were,
To see mans needless foolish fear.
Pulchrum eminere est inter illustres viros,
Consulere patriae, parcere afflictis.
'Tis brave to excell amongst worthy men, to consult for our Countreys good, and to help the afflicted.
Pulchra est concordia cordis & oris.
Tis sine to have the tongue and heart agree.
Quà flumen placidum est, forsan latet altiùs unda.
There deepest is the brook,
Where it doth smoothest look.
Quae culpare soles, ea tu ne feceris ipse.
Be not guilty of the same,
For which you do others blame.
Quae dos matronae pulcherrima? vita pudica.
What's the best portion of a Wife?
'Tis wisely answer'd, A chaste Life.
Quae casta est? de quâ mentiri fama veretur.
Who's chaste? 'tis she whose innocence most clea
That lying Gossip Fame to stain doth fear.
Quaelibet extinctos injuria suscitat ignes.
Fresh Injuries revive again,
Old grudges that had dormant lay'n.
Quaelibet iratis ipse dat arma dolor.
A man that in a Passion is, and vext,
Takes for a weapon whatso'ere lies next.
Quae virtus, & quanta bonis est vivere parvo?
It is a great vertue to be able to live contentedly on a little.
Quaerit aquas in aquis, & poma fugacia captat
Tantalus; hoc illi garrula lingua dedit.
In water Tantalus is dry,
And snaps at Apples hanging by,
But all in vain; this was his fate,
Because his tongue was given to prate.
Quae nocitura tenes, quamvis sint chara relinque.
Leave what may be hurtfull, though never so delightfull.
Quae laboriosa juventuti studia, haec sunt
Jucunda senectuti otia.
What costs us pain in Youth, will yield us pleasure in Old Age.
Quae laedunt oculos, sestinas demere: siquid
Est animum, differs curandi tempus in annum.
If but a more offend your eye,
You'l quickly seek a remedy:
If ought do ail your Soul or Mind,
A twelve-month hence the Cure's design'd,
Quaenam summa bona? mens quae sibi conscia recti.
A good Conscience is man's chiefest good.
Quae nimis apparent retia vitat avis.
Ev'n birds have wit not to come near
The nets that plainly do appear.
Quaeritur Aegisthus quare sit factus adulter?
In promptu causa est, desidiosus erat.
You ask me how Aegisthus came
With such adult'rous lust to flame;
This for the cause assign I may,
To slothfulness he did give way.
Qualem commendes etiam at{que} etiam aspice, ne mox
Incutiant aliena tibi peccata pudorem.
At first sight ne're commend a man, lest thou
Hereafter blush for him thou praisest now.
Quales ex humili magna ad fastigia rerum
Evexit, quoties voluit fortuna jocari?
Men rise to honours from the meanest birth
As oft as fortune is dispos'd to mirth.
Quàm cito (me miserum) laxantur corpora rugis,
Et perit in nitido qui fuit ore color!
'Tis sad to think, that in so small a space
To wrinkles youthful smoothness should give place,
And lively colours fade i'th' fairest face.
Quàm malè inaequales veniunt ad aratra juvenci,
Tam premitur magno conjuge nupta minor.
We count unequal Heifers in the yoke
Unsightly, just so 'tis with marryed folk.
Quam facilè irati verbo mutantur amantes!
A lovers mind with anger stirr'd,
May yet be chang'd by one small word.
Quantum quis{que} suà nummorum servat in arcà
Tantum habet & fidei. —
According to the wealth you do possess,
So also is your credit more or less.
Quantò quis{que} sibi plura negaverit,
A Diis plura feret.
The more you do your self deny,
The more expect from God most high.
— Quando{que} bonus dormitat Homerus.
The wisest man in the world may be sometimes overseen.
— Quantò felicior hic, qui
Nil cuperet, quàm qui totum sibi posceret orbem!
How much more happy is he who desires
Nothing, than he that to th' whole world aspires!
Quem ratio, non ira movet, Diis proximus ille est.
If any man is near to God above,
'Tis he whom Reason and not Rage doth move.
Quem res plus nimio delectavere secundae
Mutatae quatiunt. —
Hee'l in Adversity despond
Who of his wealth is over-fond.
Quem non mille serae, quem non Stheneleius hostis,
Non potuit Juno vincere, vicit amor.
Whom nor wild beasts, nor enemies great
Could conquer, him doth Love defeat.
Quem{que} suae rapiunt scelerara in praelia causae.
A mans own Interest doth thrust
Him upon heats. and warrs unjust.
Quemcun{que} miserum videris, hominem scias,
Quemcun{que} fortem videris, miserum neges.
Any in misery do you see,
Hence you may know them men to be:
Whom you do see still valiant,
Them miserable call you can't.
— Qui non moder abitur irae
Infectum volet èsse, dolor quod suaserit & mens.
Passion let loose too oft puts men upon
Doing what in cold blood they'l wish undone.
— Qui pauperiem veritus, potiore metallis
Libertate caret, dominum vehet improbus, at{que}
Serviet aeternum.
He that through fear of Poverty hath sold
His Liberty, which better is than Gold,
A proud imperious Lord shall alwayes have
To carry, and shall ever be a slave.
Qui metuens vivit, liber mihi non erit unquam.
He is not to be accounted free, that alwayes lives in fear.
Qui jacet in terra, non habet unde cadat.
He that lyes upon the ground cannot fall lower.
Qui ne tuberibus propriis offendat amicum,
Postulat; ignoscat verrucis illius: aequum est
Peccatis veniam poscenit reddere tursus.
He that desires his Wens should not offend
His Friend, must wink at th' pimples of his Friend.
He that would have his faults forgiven, must
Give pardon, if he take it, 'tis but just.
— Qui genus jactat suum,
Aliena laudat.
He that doth glory much in what was done
By's Ancestors, doth praise what's not his own.
Qui volucrem nutrit, pro munere stercus habebit.
They that bring up Birds shall have the dung for their reward.
Qui cupit, aut metuit, juvat illuni sic domus, aut res,
Ʋt lippum pictae tabulae, fomenta podagram.
Wealth him that craves & fears so satisfies,
As curious Pictures doe the bleared eyes,
Or Pultises the Gout, (which though they may
Give present ease, take not the Cause away.)
— Qui amant, ipsi sibi somni singunt.
Those that are in love dream strange fancies.
Qui statuit aliquid, parte inauditâ alterâ;
Aequam licet statuerit, haud aequus erit.
Such as give Sentence or award
Before they have both parties heard;
Though they should hit what's right, yet must
Such Judges needs be call'd unjust.
Qui non vetat peccare, cum possit, jubet.
He doth command sin who doth not gainsay,
Or hinder men from sinning, when he may.
Qui majora dabit munera victor erit.
He that gives the greatest gifts, shall be sure to carry the day.
Qui vult amari, languidâ regnet manu.
He must not be strict in Government that would have the Peoples love.
Qui terret, plus ille timet; sors ista tyrannis
Convenit.—
None live in so great Fear as Tyrants; who
Doe others terrifie: 'tis fitly so.
Qui se volet esse potentem,
Animos domet ille feroces;
Nec victa libidine colla
Foedis submittat habenis.
Let him, that would his valour shew,
His own affections subdue:
And let him scorn a slave to be,
Under lusts filthy tyranny.
Qui sceptra duro saevus imperio regit,
Timet timentes, metus in authorem redit.
Who strains the pins of Government too high,
Does fear them who do fear his cruelty.
Qui fingit sacros auro vel marmore vultus,
Non facit ille Deos; qui rogat, ille facit.
The man that doth an image frame,
In Marble, or in Gold, the same
Makes not an Idol; 'tis he who
Unto it prayes, that makes it so.
Qui monet ut facias qued jam facis, ille monendo
Laudat, & hortaiu comprobat acta suo.
If any doth exhort thee to
That which thou dost already doe,
By that exhorting he doth praise,
And well approve of those thy wayes.
Qui non est hodiè, cras minùs aptus erit.
He that's not fit to day, will be much less fit to morrow.
Qui satur est, pleno laudat jejunia ventre.
How good it is to fast, some men can tell
Finely, but 'tis when they have dined well.
Quique aliis cavit, non cavet ipse sibi.
Some are wife for others, but fools for themselves.
Qui semel est laesus fallaci piscis ab hamo,
Omnibus unca cibis aera subesse putat.
A Fish once by the angler struck,
In every worm suspects a hook.
Qui nil potest sperare, desperet nihil.
He that can hope for nothing, yet should not despair of any thing.
Qui metuit mortem, quod vivit perdit id ipsum.
He that is afraid of Death, loseth the very comfort of his Life.
Qui benè fecerunt, illi sua facta sequentur:
Qui malè fecerunt, facta sequentur eos.
Good men shall follow their good works,
Evil men, their evil works shall follow them.
Qui simulat verbis nec corde est fidus amicus.
He that dissembles in words, is no faithfull friend at heart.
Qui Curios simulant & Bacchanalia vivunt.
Hypocrites that make a shew of great honesty and continency, but live riotously.
Quaeris & in scyrpo (soliti quod dicere) nodum.
You are too curious in raising doubts and scruples where there is no need.
Qui sapit in tacito gaudeat ille sinu.
A truly wise man hath the soundest and most inward Joy.
Quae fugiamus habet non omnia grandior aetas.
Old age hath some things in it which are desireable.
Quicquidid est timeo Danaos & dona ferentes.
A professed Enemies gifts and seeming kindnesses are to be suspected and feared.
Quem tibi divitiae peperere est falsus amicus.
He is no trusty Friend or sure,
Whom Riches onely did procure.
Quicquid delirant Reges, plectuntur Achivi.
Kings doe amiss, and the poor people oftentimes smart for it.
Qüicquid erit superanda omnis fortuna ferendo est.
All Afflictions are to be overcome by a patient bearing of them.
Quicquid agis prudenter agas, & respice finem.
Do wisely what thou dost, and bend
Thy mind to look unto thy End.
Quicquid habet ortus finem timet, ibimus omnes.
What a beginning hath, shall also have
An end, we hasten all unto the grave.
Quicquid sub terrâ est in apricum proferet aetas:
Defodiet, condetque nitentia. —
What'ere is hidden time will bring to light,
And that will vanish which now shines so bright.
Quicquid praecipies esto brevis, ut ciso dicta
Percipiant animi dociles, teneantque fideles.
Be brief in thy Commands, that so
The docile minds may quickly know
Thy Precepts, and more faithfully
Retain them in their memory.
Quicunque solam mente praecipiti petit,
Summam{que} credit gloriam,
Late patentes aetheris cernat plagas
Arctum{que} terrarum situm.
Let him, whose mind is violently bent
Glory alone for to attain, but view
The lofty Heaven's vast and large extent,
And what a spot Earth is, compar'd thereto.
— Quid enim salvis infamia nummis?
Their Chests being full, some matter not
Disgrace or Infamy a jot.
Qui nunquam titubat vix reperitur equus.
'Tis a good Horse that never stumbles.
Quid de quoque viro, & cui dicas saepe caveto.
Beware what you speak concerning any man, and to whom you speak it.
— Quid enim Venus ebria curat?
When Drunkenness is added unto Lust,
The horrid'st villanies expect you must.
Quid? quod adulandi gens prudentissima, laudat
Sermonem indocti, faciem deformis amici.
A flatterer the speeches will commend
Of his unlearn'd, the face of 's ugly friend.
Quid non argento, quid non corrumpitur auro?
What is not corrupted by Silver and Gold?
Quid tibi divitiae prosunt, si pauper abundas?
If thou hast sufficient, what signifie Riches?
— Quid crastina volveret aetas,
Scire nefas homini. —
We know not what a day may bring forth.
Quid juvat immensum te argenti pondus & auri
Furtim defossi timidum deponere terrâ?
What good in thy vast heap of treasure's found,
Which thou by stealth dost bury under ground?
Quid sit futurum cras fuge quaerere, &
Quem fors dierum cun{que} dabit, lucro
Appone.
Upon to Morrow reckon not,
Then if it comes, 'tis clearly got.
Quid facient leges ubi sola pecunia regnat?
The force of Laws is small or none,
Where Money bears the sway alone.
Quid mentem traxisse polo, quid profuit altum
Erexisse caput? pecudum si more pererras
Avia. —
What signifies it that our Souls their birth,
From Heaven do derive, or that we may
Erect our heads, if like beasts of the Earth
We wander wholly out of Wisdoms way.
Quicquid patimur mortale genus,
Quicquid facimus venit ex alto.
Both what we suffer, and what we doe, comes down from on high.
Quid quisque vitet, nunquam homini satis Cautum est in horas.
There's no man fully knoweth what to shun,
So great's the hazard that we hourly run.
Quid non longa dies, quid non consumitis anni?
What is there that Time doth not consume and destroy?
Quid petitur sacris nisi tantùm fama poetis?
What is the Muse-inspired Poets aim,
Except to gain himself a deathless Name?
Quid faciet sapiens? stultus quoque munere gaudet.
What will the wise doe? Fools we see
Well pleas'd and glad at gifts to be.
Quid non ingenio voluit natura licere?
What is there that Wit and Ingenuity cannot accomplish?
Quid magis est durum saxo, quid mollius undâ,
Dura tamen molli saxa cavantur aquâ.
What's harder than a Stone? and yet at last
Water that's soft will stones consume and wast.
— Quidvis nummis praesentibus opta,
Et veniet. —
He that hath Money may have any thing.
Quis tulerit Gracchos de seditione querentes?
Who can endure to hear them complaining of sedition or vice, that are most seditions, or vicious?
Quippe nec ira Deûm tantum, nec tela, nec hostes;
Quantum sola noces animis illapsa voluptas.
Nor killing darts, nor rage of Man,
Nor Heaven's wrath, us injure can
So much as sinfull pleasure may,
Which slily steals our hearts away.
Quis scit an adjiciant hodiernae crastina summae Tempora Dii superi?
Who knows if God unto thy life's past score
Will please to adde one onely Morning more?
Quis labor est autem quam tacuisse minor?
What can be done with greater ease,
Than for a man to hold his peace?
Quis dives? qui nil cupiat. Quis pauper? avarius.
Who's rich? he that's contented with his store.
Who's poor? 'tis he that covets still for more.
Quis furor est atram bellis accersere mortem?
Imminet, & tacito clam venit illa pede.
Men madly call for Death by wars, as though
It did not come unsent for sast enough.
Quis legem dat amantibus?
Major lex amor est sibi.
Who can the Minds of Lovers keep in aw
By Laws? love is to them a greater Law.
Quis matrem, nisi mentis inops, in funere nati
Flere vetat? —
VVho but one void of Reason doth forbid
A mother to weep for her Child that's dead?
Quis metus aut pudor est unquam properantis avari?
What fear or shame doth greedy Minds restrain,
Who make post haste their Idol-wealth to gain?
Quisnam hominum est, quem tu contentum videris u ••
Flagitio?
Where is the man whom you contented see,
VVith the committing of one villany?
Quisnam igitur liber? sapiens, sibi{que} imperiosus:
Quem ne{que} pauperies, ne{que} mors, ne{que} vincula terren.
VVho's he that's free? descrioe to me the m • n.
'Tis he that's truly wise, and rightly can
Govern himself; whom neither poverty,
Nor Death, nor Prisons ever terrifie.
Quis nisi mentis inops oblatum respuat aurum?
VVho but a witless person, would
Refuse it, when he's offer'd Gold?
Quisquis medium defugit iter,
Stabili nunquam tramite curret.
VVhoe're the middle way doth shun,
Ne're in a stable path will run.
Quisquis habet nummos securâ naviget aurâ.
He that hath Money store may sail
VVith a secure and prosp'rous gale.
Quisquis plus justo non sapit, ille sapit.
There may be ev'n in VVisdom an excess;
VVhich he is wise indeed, that can redress.
Quisquis ubique habitat, maxime, unsquam habitat.
He that dwells every where, dwells no where.
— Quò fortuna altiùs
Evexit, at{que} levavit humanas opes;
Hoc se magis supprimere foelicem decet.
The more rich and exalted a man is, the more humble and moderate he should be.
Quò Deus, & quò dura vocat fortuna, sequamur.
Though it be ne're so hard, yet let us goe
The way, that God, and our hard lot do shew.
Quò mihi fortunas, si non conc • ditur uti?
VVhat doe I for vain Riches care,
If th'use thereof I must sorbear?
Quo pede nunc utar? dubia est sententia nobis.
VVhat I shall doe, or whither I shall betake my self, I am uncertain.
Quò plus sunt potae, plus sitiuntur aquae.
The more he drinks, the more thirsty he is.
Quo pede coepisti sic benè semper eas.
As you have begun well, so hold on and persevere unto the end.
Quò semel est imbuta recens servabit odorem Testa diu. —
VVhat seasons vessels first, the tast
Thereof they will not lose in hast.
Or,
VVhat is bred in the bone, will not out of the flesh.
Quo quis{que} est major, magìs est placabilis irae,
Et faciles motus mens generosa capit.
The greater any is, with greater ease
A Person may his kindled wrath appease.
A truly generous and noble mind
Is commonly to gentleness inclin'd.
Quòque magìs tegitur, tantò magìs aestuat ignis.
The fire, by being kept close, at length
VVill get the greater head and strength.
Quò{que} minor spes est, hoc magis ille cupit.
Some, the less hope they have, the more their desires are inslamed.
Quocun{que} ingrederis, sequitur mors, corpus ut umbra.
Death follows us wherever we goe as the shadow doth the body.
Quod caret alternâ requie, durabile non est.
That cannot last long that wants its course of rest.
Quod licet ingratum est, quod non licèt acriùs urit.
What's lawfull, many do'nt at all desire,
But what's unlawfull, sets their minds on fire.
Quod malè fers, assuesce; feres benè.
What irksome is at first, will unto thee,
Accustome but thy self to't, pleasant be.
Quod prudentis opus? cum possit nolle nocere.
What is the property o'th prudent man?
He will not evil doe, ev'n when he can.
Quod Stulti proprium? non posse & velle nocere.
How may we know a Fool? 'tis he who's short
In pow'r to hurt, but yet his will is for't.
Quod procul ab oculis, procul est à limite cordis.
Out of sight, out of mind.
Quod ratio nequiit, saepe sanavit mora.
Time and delay hath often cured that which Reason could not.
Quod refugit multi cupiunt, odere quod instat.
What offer'd is, men do disdain,
What from them flyes, they seek with pain.
Quod quis{que} fecit patitur, authorem scelus
Repetit, suo{que} premitur exemplo nocens.
A mans wickedness returns upon his own head.
Quod donare potes, gratis concede roganti.
What you can give, give freely to him that asks.
Quod venit ex facili, faciles segnes{que} tenemus.
Lightly come, lightly goe.
Quod satis est, cui contingit, nil amplius optet.
Who hath enough of Nature's store,
Let him not fondly grasp at more.
Quod meritò pateris, patienter ferre memento.
Suffer patiently, what you suffer deservedly.
Quod justum est facito, vel quod videatur honestum.
Desire what is just, or appears so to be.
Quod latet ignotum est, ignoti nulla cupido.
Men desire not what they are ignorant of.
Quod nimium est fugito, parvo gaudere memento.
Be not desirous of overmuch, but be contented with a little.
Quod sopor eripuit, credas abscedere vita.
We doe as it were not live the time that we spend in sleep.
Quod fuit durum pati, meminisse dulce est.
What is grievous to be born, is afterward sweet to remember.
Quod lautum est animo complectere, sed fuge lites.
Be merry, but not quarrelsome.
Quondam etiam victis redit in praecordia virtus.
Even the conquered sometimes retrieve their courage.
Rara avis in terris nigro{que} simillima cygno,
Vir probus. —
A Swan if black would wonder in men raise,
Just so an honest man in these our dayes.
Rara fides hominum est quia multi multa loquuntur.
Men know not what to believe, because of the diversity of Reports.
— Rara est concordia formae
At{que} pudicitiae. —
Much Beauty and unspotted Chastity seldom agree together.
— Rara est concordia fratrum.
Brothers often fall out.
Rara dari, raris{que} solet contingere virtus.
They 're every where but rare,
That truly vettuous are.
— Rara in tenui facundia panno.
Eloquence is seldom found in a thread-bare coat.
— Rarus venit in Coenacula miles.
Souldiers and Officers seldom trouble poor mens lodgings.
Rari quippe boni, vix sunt numero totidem, quot Thebarum portae, vel divitis ostia Nili.
Good men are but scarce, and their number very small.
Raro antecedentem scelestum
Deseruit pede poena claudo.
Though Punishment a while some halts doth make,
It will at last the wicked overtake.
Rebus in adversis animum submittere noli.
Let not thy heart despond in the time of Adversity.
Rebus in angustis facile est contemnere vitam:
Fortiter ille facit, qui miser esse potest.
In deep distress one's life to slight,
Affords no proof of Noble might:
He truly valiant is, who knowes
How to bear up 'gainst Fortunes blowes.
Rebus & in censu si non est, quod fuit antè;
Fac vivas contentus eo, quod tempora praebent.
If thine Estate be not as 'twas before;
Be sure thou live content with present store.
Rebus angustis animosus at{que}
Fortis appare; sapienter idem
Contrahes vento nimiùm secundo
Turgida vela.
Let thus brave courage appear in Adversity,
And thy wise moderation in prosperity.
Rectiùs vives, Licini, ne{que} altum
Semper urgendo: ne{que} dum procellas
Cautus horrescis, nimiùm praemendo
Littus iniquum.
My friend, if thou thy course would'st safely stear,
Let not thy Ship still plough the swelling deep;
Nor yet, because thou do'st foul weather fear,
Suffer it alwayes neer the shore to creep.
Rebus in adversis vera probanda fides.
True Faithfulness is tried in Adversity.
Reddere personae scit convenientia cui{que}
He knowes how to give every person his due.
Reddere qui voces jam scit puer, & pede certo
Signat humum, paribus gestit colludere, & iram
Colligit ac ponit temere, mutatur in horas.
The Child that now knows how his words to say,
And can tread firm, longs with like lads to play;
Soon angry, and soon pleas'd, is sweet, or sour,
He knows not why, and changeth every hour.
Rebus in adversis patientia vera probatur.
Presling Adversity
True patience doth trye.
Regia, crede mibi, res est succurrere lapsis.
It is a Princely thing to succour those that are in affliction.
Regis ad exemplum totus compoinitur orbis.
The People follow the example of their Prince.
— Recte fecisse bonis in parte lucrorum.
We lose nothing by shewing kindness to good men.
Reges in ipsos imperium est Jovis.
God rules over Kings themselves.
— Regi fraenis nequit
Et ira, & hostis fervens & victoria.
These things can hardly curb'd or govern'd be,
Passion, a foe incens'd, and victory.
Regem non faciunt opes,
Non vestis Tyriae color,
Non frontis nota regiae,
Non auro nitidae trabes.
They are not gawdy riches that
Do make a King, nor Princely State,
Nor Purple, nor gilt Palaces,
There must be somewhat more than these.
Rex est qui posuit metus,
Et diri mala pectoris;
Quem non ambitio impotens,
Et nunquam stabilis favor
Vulgi praecipitis movet.
A King is he, who layes aside
Both sorry fears, and devilish pride,
Whom no Ambition can deprave
Nor vulgar breath e're make a slave.
Rem tibi promissam certo promittere noli.
Do not promise another what hath been onely promised thee.
Res est soliciti plena timoris amor.
Love is a thing full of solicitous care.
Res est forma fugax, quis sapiens bono
Confidit fragili?
Beauty soon flies away; who wou'd
That's wise, trust to so frail a good?
— Res nulla minoris
Constabit patri quam filius.
Nothing shall cost many Parents less than their Children.
Res est consiliis secura fidelibus uti.
It is a safe thing to make use of faithful counsel.
Res malè tuta viros linguâ irritare protervâ.
It is no safe thing to provoke men by sawey language.
Res age quae prosunt, rursus vitare memento
In quibus error inest, nec spes est certa laboris.
Mind things which profit, and again eschew
Such as have errors whence no good ensue.
Rem pateris modicam, & mediocri bile ferendam.
Si flectas oculos majora ad crimina. —
We may well bear afflictions patiently, when we consider that our sins are greater than our afflictions.
Ridetur chordâ qui semper oberrat eadem.
The blind Harper makes slender Musick, that alwayes playes upon one string.
Rex solum aut vates non quovis nascitur anno.
Kings and Prophers are not born every year.
— Ridentem dicere verum Quid vetat? —
For to blurt our a Truth ha's never been
(In way of merriment) esteem'd a sin.
Religionis enim fonstimor, amnis amor.
Religion begins by Fear, but proceeds by Love.
Ridentur mala qui componunt carmina: verum
Gaudent scribentes, & se venerantur, & ultro
Si taceas laudant quicquid scripsere beati.
Verses indeed, if bad, there's nothing worse,
Nor more ridiculous; yet some Fools of course
Love to be scribling, and themselves extoll,
For that, at which all others laugh and droll.
— Rides? majore cachinno
Concutitur: flet, si lachrymas conspexit amici,
Nec dolet: igniculum brumae si tempore poscas,
Accipit endromidem: si dixeris aestuo, sudat.
Smile you? a louder laughter shakes him: weep?
He his friend company, in tears, will keep,
But grieves not; if you say, the winter's cold,
And call for fire, he'l in a rug be roll'd;
Cry but 'tis hot, he sweats; the Parasite
Dissembles thus, and playes the hypocrite.
Ridet amicitias, curat sua commoda tantum.
He laughs at Friendship, and regards onely his own advantage.
Ridebat curas nec non & gaudia vulgi Democritus. —
Laughter Democritus could not restrain,
To see mens foolish cares, and joyes more vain.
Rode, caper, vites; tamen hic cum stabis ad aras
In tua quod fundi cornua possit, erit.
Thou carp'st at others, Zoilus, have a care,
If thou abroad appear'st, thee they'l not spare.
Romae Tybur amo, ventosus Tybure Romam.
When I'me at Rome, I'de fain at Tybur be;
And when at Tybur, Rome I long to see.
Roma dìu titubans, variis erroribus acta,
Corruet, & mundi desinet esse caput.
Rome, reeling long with sundry Errors press'd,
Down tumble shall and let the world have rest.
Rumor, ut est velox, agitatis pervolat alis.
Reports flee up and down apace.
Rumores fuge, ne incipias novus author haberi.
Delight not in reports, lest thou come to be accounted a raiser of them.
Rumor rumores, errores parturit error.
One report and mistake often-times brings forth another.
Rumpitur innumeris arbos uberrima pomis,
Et subito nimiae praecipitantur opes.
As too much fruit the boughs has often broke,
So wealth excessive does the Owners choke.
Rure ego viventem, tu dicis in urbe beatum.
Mens Minds are very various; I preferre
The Countrey, thou the Town as happler.
Rustica paulatim taurus aratra subit.
By little and little the Bull is broke,
And comes to buckle to the yoke.
Rustica gens semper genus indomabile, semper
Irrequietum animal, gaudet sudore.
Rusticks are a sort of People untractable, and restless, delighting in toyling.
Rursus amor Patriae ratione potentior omni.
The love of one's Countrey, is of great force.
Saepe etiam est Olitor valde opportuna locutus.
A mean person may sometimes speak to the purpose.
Saepe in Magistrum scelera redierunt sua.
A mans wickedness often-times returns upon his own head.
Saepe simultates ira morata facit.
Anger ablding too long, oft-times begets hatred.
Saepe loquax verbis proditur ipse suis.
A Babler oft betrayes,
Himself, by what he sayes.
Saepe patris mores imitatur silius insans
The Infant Son doth often shew
His Fathers Face, and Manners too.
Saepe perit ventis obruta cymba suis.
A Vessel often-times doth by
Her own winds perish utterly.
Saepe solent auro multa subesse mala.
From Gold, though ne're so glorious in mens eyes,
Innumerable Evils do arise.
Saepe sub attritâ latitat sapientia veste.
Under a thread-bare Coat we find
Sometimes a wise and piercing mind.
Saepe tacens vocem verba{que} vultus habet.
Though a man holds his peace, yet his very countenance sometimes has a kind of voice in it.
Saepe tacens odii semina vultus habet.
A silent Countenance hath oft-times in it the seeds of hatred.
Saepius incautae nocuit victoria turbae.
Conquest it self hath sometimes harm'd
Those who with care have not been arm'd.
— Saevit toto Mars impius orbe.
Blood-thirsty Mara in this our Age,
Vents every where his deadly rage.
— Saevis inter se convenit ursis.
Even the savage Bears agree
Amongst themselves; and shall not we?
Saevum praelustri fulmen ab arce venit.
The neerer the Court, the neerer danger.
Saevus amor docuit natorum sanguine matrem Commaculare manus.
Where lustfull Love prevails, even Mothers will Their own poor Childrens blood not stick to spill.
Scilicet est cupidus studiorum quisque suorum.
Every one is desirous of his own studies.
Scilicet ingenium, & rerum prudentia velox,
Ante pilos venit. —
Young men do dream of store of Wisdom, when Their smoother chins do scarce declare them men.
Scilicet ingenium placidâ mollitur ab arte.
Mens dispositions are made more gentle by the ingenuous Arts.
Scilicet insano nemo in amore videt,
Love is blind.
Scilicet in vulgus manant exempla regentûm.
The Example of Rulers has a great influence on the common people.
Scilicet ut fulvum spectatur in ignibus aurum,
Tempore sic duro est inspicienda fides.
As Gold is try'd in the fire, so is the faithfulness of a friend in Adversity.
— Scilicet ultima semper
Expectanda dies homini est, dici{que} beatus
Aute obitum nemo suprema{que} funera debet.
Death must be look'd for still, there's none that can
Till that time come, be term'd a happy man.
(23) Scilicet expectas, ut tradat mater honestos
Aut alios mores, quam quos habet? —
Do you expect a Mother shou'd
Be like to make her daughter good,
When she her self was never so?
How can she, what she has not, shew?
Scilicet uxorem cum dote, fidem{que} & amicos,
Et genus, & formam, regina Pecunia donat.
This mighty Monarch Money, to us sends
Fair Wives, great Portions, Reputation, Friends,
This makes us Noble, though our Birth be base,
And gives our Persons comeliness and grace.
Scinditur incertum studia in contraria vulgus.
The Common people are of different minds.
— Saepe Diespiter
Neglectus incesto add ••• t integrum.
Oft God neglected, makes the just
To smart with those are stain'd with lust.
— Sapiens uno minor est Jove; dives,
Liber, honoratus, pulcher; Rex denique Regum.
A truly wise man is to none
Inferiour, but to God alone,
Rich, free, fair, noble, every thing,
He's somewhat greater than a King.
Scandit aeratas vitiosa naves
Cura: nec turmas equitum relinquit,
Ocyor cervis, & agente nimbos
Ocyor Euro.
Take horse, rude care will ride behind;
Embarque, into thy Ship she crowds:
Fleeter than Staggs, and the East-wind
Chacing the Clouds.
Scire volam quantum simplex hilarisque nepoti.
Discrepet, & quantum discordet parcus avaro.
I would fain know the difference between the cheerfull liberal Man, and the Prodigal; between the thrifty saving Man, and the Covetous.
Scire aliquid laus est, pudor est nil discere velle.
Knowledge is commendable, 'tis a shame not to be willing to learn.
Scire tuum nihil est, nisi te scire hoc sciat alter.
What you know signifies but little, unless it appears to others that you know it.
Scire volunt secreta domus, at{que} inde timeri.
Some would know others secrets, and from thence keep them in fear.
Scribendi rectè sapere est, & principiunt & sons.
Wisdom is the Principle and Spring of writing well.
Scribimus indocti, doctique poemata passim.
Both learned and unlearned men do take
Upon them every where Poems to make.
Scrutamur rimas, evertimus omne profundum
Quaeritur argentisemen, nunc durea vena.
No Chink's unsought, no deep unturn'd remains,
To find the Golden and the Silver Veins.
Sed fugit interea, fugit irreparabile tempus.
From fleeing there is none can Time restrain,
It flies away, never to come again.
Sed samae invigilare decet, quis nisset Nomerum
Ilias aeternum si latuisset opus?
We may seek Fame; who had known Homers Name,
Had not the Iliads declar'd the same?
— Sed quid violentius aure Tyranni?
What is more violent than a Tyrants car?
Sed tamen amoto quaeramus seria ludo.
Let us leave trifling, and be serious.
Sed laudat siliquae occultus ganeo • pulses
Coram aliis dictat puero, sed in aure placentas.
Some men that close and secret Gluttons are,
Will notwithstanding praise an homely fare;
And bid their Servants fetch, if others hear,
Brown loaves, but whisper Junkets in their car.
Sed plures nimiâ congesta pecunia curâ
Strangulat. —
Money layd up with too much care,
Does unto many prove a snare.
Sed tamen apparet dissimulatus amor,
Love can't be hid.
Sed propera, nec re venturas differ in horas.
Make haste, and don't give way to negligent delay.
Sed non permittit locupletem ópulentìa rerum
Carpere tranquillâ securam nocte quietem.
Wealth does its owner often keep
Waking, when he should take his sleep.
— Sed nulla aconita bibuntur
Fictilibus, tune illa time, cum pocula sumas,
Gemmata. —
In vessels that of Earth are made,
No Poyson's drunk, then be afraid
Of poyson, when there's in thy hands
A Cup beset with Diamonds.
Sed mora tuta brevis, lentescunt tempore curae.
There's safety sometimes in a short delay,
Cares that most grievous are, in time decay.
Sed non implevit cupientes omnia mentes
Quicquid fodit Iber, quicquid Tagus extulit auri.
All the Gold in the world cannot satisfie a covetous mind.
Sed tacitus pasci si posset corvus, haberet
Plus dapis, & rixae multo minus, invidiaeque.
The Crow had fared better, if he had not cryed roast-meat.
Segnius irritant animos demissa per aures,
Quam quae sunt oculis subjecta fidelibus. —
That makes not such Impression which comes in
By th'ears, as what by th'saithful eyes is seen.
— Semita certê
Tranquillae per virturem pater unica vitae.
Vertue is the only way to a peaceable and quiet life.
Semper avarus eget, certum voto pete finem.
The cov'tous alwayes want, do thou intend
In thy desires some certain fixed end.
Semel emissum volat irrevocabile verbum.
A word once out of the mouth cannot be recalled.
Semper enim vacuus currit ab urbe Cliens.
The Client alwayes runs from the City with an empty Purse.
Semper inoblitâ repetam tua munera mente.
I will alwayes remember your kindnesses.
Seriùs aut citiùs sedem proper amus ad unam.
Sooner or later we must all die.
Sermo hominum mores, & celat, & indicat idem.
Speech doth conceal, Speech also doth declare
What a Man's temper and his manners are.
Sermo datur cunctis, animi sapientia paucis.
To all men Nature Speech hath given,
Few are with wisdom bless'd from Heaven.
Serò clypeum post vulnera sumis.
When the Steed is stollen, 'tis too late to shut the Stable door.
Serum est cavendi tempus in medíís malis.
In the midst of evils, 'tis too late to take beed.
Sequitur superbos ultor à tergo Deus.
God resisteth the proud.
Si benè quid facias, facias cito, nam cito factum
Gratum erit: ingratum gratia tarda facit.
If that thou dost a kindness show,
Do't quickly; 'twill the better take,
And more oblige; a kindness slow
The person do's unthankfull make.
Si Christum bene scis, satis est, si caetera nescis;
Si Christum nescis, nihil est, si caetera discis.
If you know Christ well, it is no matter though you are ignorant of many other things:
If you are ignorant of Christ, other knowledge will avall but little.
Sic ne perdiderit, non cessat perdere lusor.
Gamesters goe on to loose in play
Lest they should loosers goe away.
Sic plerique sinunt, veros elabier hostes
Et quos nulla gravat noxia, dente petunt.
True enemies men suffer to goe free,
And them they prosecute that harmless be.
Sic volo, sic jubeo, sit pro ratione voluntas.
Thus I do will, thus I command,
My will shall for a reason stand.
Si damnosa senem Juvat alea, ludit & haeres.
When the old man is given to game,
His Son's addicted to the same.
Si fortuna volet fies de Rhetore Consul,
Si volet haec eadem fies de Consule Rhetor.
If Fortune will, poor Rhetoriclan, she
Can raise thee, and thou shalt a Consul be;
And from a Consul, if she will, she can
Make thee again a Rhetorician.
Si modo non census nec clarum nomen avorum,
Sed probitas magnos ingenium{que} facit.
It is not wealth, and an high pedigree
That makes men great, but wit and honesty.
Simplicibus praesens Deus est, offenditur astu.
God loveth plain and single hearts,
But hateth crast and guile full Arts.
Sincerum est nisi vas, quodcun{que} infundis, acescit.
A vessel when not right, will soure,
Whatever you into it pour.
Si ventri bene, si lateri est, pedibus{que} tuis, nil
Divitiae poterunt regales addere majus.
If thou hast got good diet, and warm cloaths,
The Kings Estate can't give thee more than those.
Si pranderet olus patienter, regibus uti
Nollet Aristippus, si sciret regibus uti,
Fastidiret olus, qui me notat.
Diogenes said, that Aristippus would
Refuse the fare of Princes, if he could
Dine patiently on Sallads; He again
Said that the Cynick would his herbs disdain,
Did he but know the way to gratifie
And humour Kings, and by them feasted be.
Si tibi nulla sitim sintret copia lymphae,
Narrares Medicis: quod quanto plura parâsti,
Tantò plura cupis, nulline faterier audes?
If such a thirst were your disease,
As all you drink could not appease,
You'd tell the Doctor on't: yet when
The more your wealth comes flowing in,
The more you covet still for gain,
Of this disease won't you complain?
— Si vis me flere, dolendum est.
Primum ipsi tíbi, tunc tua me infortunia laedent.
If thou wouldst have me weep, be thou first drown'd
Thy self in tears, then me thy griefs will wound.
Si lubeat servare procul quoque Numina possùnt.
If God please, he can save afar off as well as neer.
Si metuis, si prava cupis, si duceris irâ,
Servitii patiere jugum, tolerabis iniquas
Interius leges. —
Fear, ill desires, and passion, these three
Subject men to the vilest slavery.
Saepe latet molit coluber subgraminis umbrâ.
Oft-times a Snake lies hid under the greenest Grass.
— Si quid novisti rectius istis,
Candidus imperti; si non, his utere mecum.
If you know ought that better is
Than what I offer, be so kind
As to impart, if not, let this
Of mine fair entertainment find.
Si mihi difficilis formam natura negavit,
Ingenio formae damna rependo meae.
Am I without external Beauty born?
My want of Beauty, I'le with VVit adorn.
Si proceres peccant, si peccavere parentes;
Exemplo & sceleri poena paranda duplex.
If great men, and if Parents swerve,
Double punishment they deserve,
Because they sin, and also doe
To others bad Examples shew.
Si Natura negat, sacit indignatio versum.
If Nature verses won't endite,
Me indignation shall excite.
Si quoties peccant homines, sua fulmina mittat
Jupiter, exiguo tempore inermis erit.
If full as oft as men offend,
Thunder-bolts should upon them light;
God quickly would want bolts to send,
[Or rather have no man to smite.]
Si genus humanum & mortalia temnitis arma,
At sperate Deum memorem fandi atque nefandi.
Though man with all his pow'r you don't regard;
Yet know there is a God that will reward.
Siqua venit serò, magna ruina venit.
Punishment, the longer 'tis before it comes, the more heavy 'tis when it comes.
Si potes, ignotis etiam prodesse memento.
If you can, doe good even to strangers.
Sit tibi praecipuè, quod primum est, cura salutis.
Have an especial care of your health.
Sint Maecenates, non deerunt, Flacce, Marones.
Let there be encouraging Patrons, and there will not want learned men.
Sit piger ad poenas princeps, ad praemia velox.
A Prince should be slow to punish, and swift to reward.
Sit tibi praecipuae cordis custodia curae.
Keep your Heart with an especial care.
Sollicitae mentes speque metuque pavent.
Sollicitous minds are perplex'd between Fear and Hope.
Sollicitumque aliquid laetis intervenit—
Some sorrow is mixt with the greatest joy.
Solamen miseris socios habuisse doloris.
'Tis some comfort to have company in sorrow.
Solvitur omne decus letho, niveos{que} per artus
It Stygius color.—
Death spoyls the freshest beauty, and soon can
Make the pure snow-like joynts look pale & wan.
Spem retine, spes una hominem nec morte relinquit.
Keep up good Hope, which will not fosake thee.
Sperne voluptates, nocet empta dolore voluptas.
From pleasures carefully abstain,
That pleasure hurts that's bought with pain.
Spes bona sollicito victa timore ca dit.
Then comfortable hopes do fail,
When cold and sullen fears prevail.
Spernere magnanimos omnia dura decet.
It becomes a magnanimous person to despise all difficulties.
Spes alit agricolas, spes sulcis credit aratis
Semina, quae magno foenore reddit ager.
Hope feeds the Husband-man, hope sowes the ground
Which will in time to good account redound.
Spem vultu simulat, premit altum corde delorem.
Hope in his countenance he feigns,
His deep and inward grief restrains.
Speraret coelos nemo, si nemo timeret
Infera.—
The fear of Hell quickens mens hopes and endeavours after Heaven.
Sperat infestis, metuit secundis,
Alteram sortem bene praeparatum
Pectus.
The mind that's well prepar'd, and right,
Will hope, when Fortune wreaks her spight,
And when he prospers, he will bear,
In mind the other lot, and fear.
Stat sua cui{que} dies, breve & irreparabile tempus
Omnibus est vitae; sed famam extendere factis
Hoc virtutis opus.—
Man's time prefixed is, and short to all,
Which when once gone, there's none can it recall;
Only brave Souls by vertue do extend
Their Honour so that it shall ne're have end.
Stemmata quid faciunt? quid prodest Pontice long •
Sanguine censeri, pictos{que} ostendere vultus
Majorum, & stantes in curribus Aemylianos?
What's there in great Birth, and long Pedigrees,
What doth it profit for to represent
Our great Ancestors with their victories,
And noble deeds in Statue or in paint?
Stet quicunque volet potens.
Aulae culmine lubrico;
Me dulcis saturet quies
Obscuro positum loco.
Let who will take the Honours great
O'th Court, which are most slippery;
Sweet rest, though in an homely Seat,
Doth my mind better satisfie.
Strangulat inclusus dolor, at{que} cor aestuat intus.
Grief kept in and smother'd overwhelms, and rageth the more.
Stulte, quid est somnus gelidae nisi mortis imago?
What is Sleep, but the Image of Death?
Stultitiam simulare loco prudentia summa est.
A point of wisdom 'tis to make a shew
Of Folly, when Occasion leads thereto.
—Suave est ex magno tollere acervo.
It's sweet taking from a large heap.
Stultus uter{que} locum immeritum causatur iniquê,
In culpa est animus.—
Fools with the place fault falsly find,
When all the fault is in their mind.
— Sua vulnera nutrit
Qui tegit.—
He that conceals his griess, nourisheth them.
Sub lare privato tutiùs esse licet.
There's more safety in a private and retired dwelling.
Sed nunquam dederìs spaciosum tempus in iram.
Be not angry long.
Summum crede nefas animam praeferre pudori,
Et propter vitam vivendi perdere causas.
We may it for the worst sin take,
Before our honour for to choose
Ev'n Life it self; and for the sake
Of Life, the end of Life to loose.
Spes bona dat vires, animum quo{que} spes bona servat,
Vivere spe vidi, qui moriturus crat.
Hope giveth strength, hope doth the mind revive,
I've seen a dying man by hope to live.
Sit facilis victus nullo irritante sapore.
Be moderate in your dyet.
Summa petit livor, perstant alrissima venti,
Summa petunt dextrà fulmina missa Jovis.
Envy at things that are most high do's strike.
Thunder-bolts also, and Winds do the like.
Tabida consumit ferrum lapidemque vetustas.
Time consumes even Stones and Iron;
Tales ergo cibi, qualis domus, atque suppellex.
Such as your house and things about you are,
'Tis most agreeing such should be your fare.
Tantalus in mediâ garrulus aret aqua.
The prating Tantalus is dry,
Though store of Water runneth by.
Tantum aevi longinqua valet mutare vetustas.
Time makes great Alterations;
Tantis parta malis, cura majore, metu{que}
Servantur. —
Riches which with much trouble gotten are,
Are also kept with greater fear and care.
Tarda solet magnis rebus inesse fides.
Great things are slowly and hardly believed.
Tecum habita; & naris quam sit tibi curta supellex.
Dwell with thy self, and know how poor
And short thou art in all thy store.
Tempora labuntur tacitisque senescimus annis.
Time slides away apace, and hoary hair
Upon us steals before we are aware.
Temporibus medicina valet, data tempore prosunt,
Et data non apto tempore vina nocent.
Physick doth good in time, and so most things,
And Wine not given in season damage brings.
Tempore quae{que} suo qui facil, ille sapit.
He is a wise man indeed that doth all things in their proper season.
Tempora ne culpes, cum sis tibi causa doloris.
Do not blame the time when thou thy self art the cause of thine own sorrow.
Tempore in exiguo sugiunt mala gaudia vitae.
Life's ill joy and delight
Doth quickly take its flight;
Tempus edax rerum, tu{que} invidiosa vetustas,
Omnia destruitis. —
Time and Age destroy all things.
Tempora si fuerint nubila, solus eris.
If storms arise, you shall
Forsaken be by all.
Tempora mutantur, & nos mutamur in illis.
The times great changes suffer do,
And we are changed in them too.
Tempore difficiles veniunt ad aratra juvenci.
Time brings the sturdy Heifers for to bow
Their necks, and buckle to the painfull plough.
Tempora longa tibi noli promittere vitae.
Do not promise thy self a long life, or many years.
Tendimus huc omnes metam properamus ad unam.
We are all hastning to the same common end.
— Tenet insanabile multos
Scribendi cacoethes, & aegro in corde senescit.
The wanton itch of writing, a disease
That few are cur'd of, doth on many seize.
Terra malos homines nunc educat, atque pusillos.
By th'earth produced men are now,
Both wicked, and in stature low.
Terra domus non est animis accommoda nostris,
Altiùs it nostrae conditionis honor.
The Earth is not a dwelling place
Unto our Souls accommodate:
Our Souls are sprung of higher race,
And look for a much better state.
Terra salutiferas herbas, eadem{que} nocentes
Nutrit, & urticae proxima saepe rosa est.
Earth that common Parent breeds
Wholsome herbs and hurtfull weeds;
Oftentimes the Nettle growes
Very near unto the Rose.
Temperie coeli corpus{que} animus{que} juvantur.
Body and Mind are helped by
The temp'rature of th' heavens high.
— Timidi nunquam statuere trophaeum.
Faint heart never won fair Lady.
— Timidis & suspectis aptissima mors est.
Death is most meet and fit for them that are
Full of suspicion and slavish Fear.
— Timor & minae
Scaudunt codem quò Dominus: neque
Decedit aerata triremi, &
Post equitem sedet atra cura.
Pale fear and dangers haunt their Lord
Into all places: and black care
Behind him rides: or if on board
A Ship, 'tis his companion there.
Tolle moras, semper nocuit differre paratis.
Delayes are dangerous.
Tollere nodosam nescit medicina podagram.
Few Medicines are sure
The knotty gout to cure.
— Tolluntur in altum
Ʋt lapsu graviore cadant. —
They are lifted up on high, that their fall may be the greater.
Tota licet veteres exornent undi{que} cerae
Atria, nobilitas sola est atque unica virtus.
Though thy Courts full of Wax-effigies be,
Vertue's the only true Nobility.
Tranquillas etiam naufragus horret aquas.
The burnt Child dreads the fire.
Tres mihi covivae prope dissentire videntur,
Poscentes vario multum diversa Palato:
Quid dem? quid non dem? renuis tu, quod jubet alter;
Quod petis, id sanè est invisum acidum{que} duobus.
'Tis ten to one, if I three Friends invite,
Each one is of a different appetite:
What should I give, or not give? one does choose
And call for what the other doth refuse,
And what the third doth greatly like, is by
The other two counted unsavoury.
— Trahit sua quemque voluptas.
Every one as he likes.
Tros Tyrius{que} mihi nullo diserimine agetur.
I will make no partial difference.
Tranquillis rebus quae sunt adversa caveto.
When you are in prosperity, beware of Adversity.
— Tractent fabrilia fabri.
Let every one keep the bounds of his own calling.
Tu me inter strepitus nocturnos atque diurnos
Vis canere. —
Can you expect I study should, or write,
Amidst such noyses both by day and night?
Tu recte vivis si curas esse quod audis.
You live right, if you live according to
The good report that goes abroad of you.
Tu quoqus formida nimiùm suldimia semper
Propositi{que} memor contrahe velatui.
Contract your Sails, and carefully
Alwayes shun things that are too high
Tu quamcunque Deus tibi fortunaverit horam,
Grata sume manu, nec dulcia differ in annum.
Whatever hour God prosperous shall make,
With thankfulness its present sweetness take.
Tu ne cede malis sed contra audentior ito.
Doe not give way to dangers, but goe on the more courageously.
Tu nihil invitâ dices faciesve Minervâ.
From all such words and actions abstain,
As seem to go against thy Nature's grain.
Tu quoque factimeas, & quae tibi laeta videntur,
Dum loqueris fieri tristia posse puta.
Keep mod'rate Fear: think that thy comsorts may
Unto thee crosses prove another day.
Tu ne quaesieris scire (nefas) quem mihi, quem tibi
Finem Dii dederint Leucothoe, nec Babylonios
Tentâris numeros. —
I would not have thee to enquire, my Friend,
(It is a piece of wickedness) what end
God will give thee or me: nor dare to goe
To vain Astrologers thy Fate to know.
Tu civem patremque geras; tu consule cunctis,
Nec tibi, nec tua te moveant, sed publica vota.
Be publick spirited, to seek the good of others, and of the publick, and not your own private interest alone.
— Tu semper amoris
Sit memor, & chari comitis ne abscedat imago.
Remember me when you do not see me.
— Tunc omnia jur'a tenebis,
Cum poteris rex esse tui. —
If thou canst govern thy self rightly, then
Thou'lt well observe all Laws of God and Men.
Turpe reserre pedem, nec passu stare tenaci.
It is a shame to turn back from ones purpose through light inconstancy.
Turpe laborantem daseruisse ratem.
It is shamefull to leave a Friend in danger.
Turpe quidem dictu, sed si modo vera fatemur,
Vulgus amicùias utilitate probat.
'Tis shamefull, yet we find it so to be,
Most judge of Friendship by utility.
Turpe pecus mutilum, turpis sine gramine campus,
Et sine fronde frutex, & sine crine caput.
Comeliness these things have none,
Cattel maimed, and fields bare
Of grass, trees whose leaves are gone,
And the head that hath no hair.
Turpe duci somno totam consumere noctem,
O Rector Lybiae vi • ili stant bella magistro.
A General in War must watchfull keep,
For him 'tis not fit the whole night to sleep.
Turpe sene • miles, turpe senilis amor.
To see an old man list himself for War,
Or fall in love, both most uncomely are.
Turpiùs ejicitur, quam non admittitur hospes.
An ill guest is better kept out, than cast out when once admitted.
Tuta frequens{que} via est per amici fallere nomen;
Tuta frequensqylicet sit, via crimen habet.
By th' shew of Friendship, though to undermine
Be safe and common, 'tis an hainous crime.
Tutius est igitur fictis contendere verbis,
Quam pugnare manu. —
It is safer chiding, than fighting.
Turpis amor surdis auribus esse solet.
Love is deaf.
Turpius est pulchrâ nam meretrice nihil.
Nothing is more foul than a fair harlot.
— Valet ima summis
Mutare, & insignem attenuat Deus
Obscura promens.—
God can the lofty and the proud abase,
And lift the mean unto an higher place.
— Varium & mutabile semper
Foemina.—
Women are unconstant.
Velle suum cuique est, nec voto vivitur uno.
All are not of a mind.
Venturae memores jam nunc estote senectae.
Ev'n now whilst youth and strength do last,
Be mindfull that old age makes haste.
Verba in consilis, valet in certamine robur.
In Counsel Words and Eloquence go far,
I'th'battel strength and courage needfull are.
Verba puellarum foliis leviora caducis.
There is not much weight in a maids words.
Ver non una dies, non una reducit hirundo.
One swallow makes not a summer.
Verus amor nullum novit habere modum.
True Love knowes no measure.
Victa jacet pietas, & virgo caede madente,
Ʋltima coelestum terras Astraea reliquit.
Godliness doth despised lye,
And Justice hath the Earth forsaken,
Which so abounds with cruelty;
And hath her flight to Heaven taken.
Victaque pugnaci jura sub ense jacent.
Justice and Laws expelled are
By the rude Sword of bloody War.
Victor cum victis pariter miscebitur umbris.
The Conquerer and conquer'd have
No difference at all i'th Grave.
Vilius argentum est auro, virtutibus aurum.
Silver to Gold, and Gold much more
To vertue is inferiour.
Vino forma perit, vino corrumpitur aetas.
Beauty and Age do much decline
By the immoderate use of Wine.
Vina sitim sedent, natis Venus alma creardis
Serviat, hos fines transiliisse nocet.
Of Wine to quench your thirst partake,
Of Copulation too make use
Only for Procreation sake;
T'exceed these bounds doth harm produce.
Vim temperatam Dii quoque provehunt
In majus, iidem odère viros
Omne nefas animo moventes.
Force that is temp'rate God doth help and bless,
But hates strength that provokes to wickedness.
Vince animos, iramque tuam, qui caetera vincis.
Thou that overcomest other things, overcome thy self and thy own passion.
Vincere cùm possis, interdum cede sodali.
— Vir bonus est quis?
Though thou can'st conquer thy Companion, yet sometimes yield to him.
Qui consulta patrum, qui leges juraque servat.
Who's a good man? 'tis he that does not swerve
From ancient rights, but does 〈…〉 d • serve.
Viribus hic praestat, hic pollet acumine mentis;
Nec tamen alterius non gget alter ope.

In wisdom some, others in stren •••
〈◊〉 ;
However still each th'others help • oth need.
Vincuntur molli pectora dura prece.
Hearts that most stiff and rugged are,
Are yet o'recome by humble Pray'r.
Virtutem primam esse puta compescere linguam:
It is a principal vertue to bridle ones tongue.
— Virtute decet non sanguine niti.
It becomes us to relye upon Vertue, and not upon our Descent.
Virtutem incolumem odimus,
