Sublatam ex oculis quaerimus invidi.
We hate and envy worthy men
So long as they alive remain;
But when away they 're taken, then
We wish to have them here again.
Virtus est vitium sugere, & sapientia prima
Stultitiâ caruisse.—
'Tis Vertue to avoid Vice carefully,
Folly to want, is wisdom's first degree.
Virtus repulsae nescia sordidae,
Intaminatis fulget honoribus:
Nec sumit aut ponit secures
Arbitrio popularis aurae.
Vertue, that ne're repulse admits,
In purest honours shining sits;
Nor takes, not leaveth Dignities,
Mov'd with the noyse of vulgar cryes.
Virtus recludens immeritis mori
Coelum, negatâ tentat iter viâ:
Coetusque vulgares & udam
Spernit humum sugiente penna.
Vertue Heav'n opening to them
That aim at Immortality,
Doth force her passage, and contemn
The Vulgar's sorry company:
And scorning this mean Earth and Mire,
Doth bravely mount to something higher.
Vis sapiens dici? raro & meditata loquare.
Would you be esteemed wise? speak but little, and consider before you speak.
Vis consilii expers mole ruit suâ.
Force without Counsel shall,
Crush'd by its own weight, sall.
Vitaret coelum Phaeton si viveret.—
Rash and unhappy Phaeton would shun,
Were he alive the Charet of the Sun.
Vita decer sacros & pagina casta Poetas,
Castus enim vatum spiritus at{que} sacer.
Both the Lives and the Writings of Poets should be as their Spirits, chaste and holy.
— Vitiant artus aegrae contagia mentis.
The distempers of the mind have a great influence upon the body.
Vitae summa brevis spemmos vetat inchoare long am.
The shortness of our Life forbids long designs.
Vive tibi, quantum{que} potes, praelustriá vita.
Enjoy your self, and (what you can) shun things that are too high.
Vivitur exiguo meliùs, natura beatis
Omnibus esse dedit, si quls cognoverit uri.
Upon a little we may better live;
Bountifull Nature doth to all men give
That which may them content and satisfie,
If they know how to use it prudently.
Vivitur ex rapto, non hospes ab hospite tutus.
Man in this Iron Age preys on his Brother,
The Host and Guest are not safe one from th'other.
Vivitur parvo bend, cui paternum
Splendet in mensâ tenuisalinum:
Nec leves somnos timor aut Cupido
Sordidus aufert.
His little's much, whose thrifty board
Shines with a Salt that was his Sires;
Whose casie sleeps nor fears disturb,
Nor base desires.
Vivendum est rectè, cum propter plurima, tum his
Praecipuè causis, ut linguas mancipiorum
Contemnas.—
We must for many causes live upright,
But chiefly that we Servants tongues may slight.
Vivitur ingenio, caetera mortis erunt.
We live by th'goods of mind alone, what we
Enjoy besides, to death must subject be.
Verùm ubi plura nitent in carmine, non ego paucis
Offendor maculis.—
Where in a Poem I much shining see,
With a few spots I'le not offended be.
Ʋna salus victis nullam sperare salutom.
The vanquished this safety have alone,
That good or safety they can hope for none.
Ʋnicui{que} dedit vitium natura creato.
Every one hath his Faults.
Ʋnus Pellaeo juveni non sufficit orbis.
One World was not enough for great Alexanders Mind.
Ʋna eadem{que} manus vulnus opem{que} feret.
The same hand breaks the head, and gives a plaister.
Vox audita perit, litera scripta manet.
Words heard away do slide,
What's written doth abide.
— Voluptates commendat rarior usus.
Pleasures are so much the better, by how much more seldom used.
Ʋtendum est aetate, cito pede praeterit aetas.
Make use of time, for it steals away apace.
Ʋt jugulent homines surgunt de nocte latrones;
Ʋt teipsum serves, non expergisceris?—
Do Thieves to kill men break their sleep, & shou'd
Not we awake for our own greatest good?
Ʋt desint vires, tamen est laudanda voluntas.
Where strength is wanting, the good will is to be accepted for the deed.
Ʋt sit magna, tamen certè lenta ira Deorum est.
Although God's wrath be great we know,
Yet is he unto anger slow.
Ʋt Venus enervat vires, sic copia Bacchi
Attenuat gressus, debilitat{que} pedes.
Both Venery and Wine do greatly prey
Upon mans strength, and cause it to decay.
Ʋt nemo in sese tentat descendere, nemo:
Sed praecedenti spectatur mantica tergo.
Men observe and search into others faults, few or none into their own.
— Ʋt ameris amabilis esto.
Carry your self in a lovely Manner, that you may be loved.
Ʋt quantum generi demas, virtutibus addas.
What from my Birth you take away,
You must unto my Vertues pay.
Ʋt veniant gemmae totus transibitur orbis.
Men will travel all the world over for Jewels.
Ʋt fragilis glacies, interit ira morâ.
Anger's asswaged by delay
As brittle Ice doth melt away.
Ʋtile doctrinis praebere senilibus aures.
It is profitable to hearken unto old mens Instructions.
Ʋtile consilium dominus ne despice servi.
Do not despise usefull counsel, though it be thy Servant that gives it thee.
Ʋtere quaesitis opibus, suge nomen avari.
Make use of your riches, and avoid the Name of a Miser.
— Ʋt discas vivere, disce mori.
If you would learn to live, learn to dye.
Ʋvaque conspectâ livorem ducit ab uvâ.
One rotten Grape tains another.
Ʋtere quaesitis modicè, dum sumptus abundet.
Be moderate in your expences.
Ex oculo lachrymas elicit intus amor.
Love sometimes forceth tears out of the eye,
And causeth it to wear griefs Livery.
Ex vatum ingeniis multorum gloria pendet.
The glory of many depends upon the Wits of Poets.
Excitat auditor studium, laudata{que} virtus
Crescit.—
Hearers much greater industry do raise,
And Vertue is it self increas'd by Praise.
— Exeat aulâ
Qui volet esse pius, virtus & summa potestas
Non coeunt.—
The man that doth design to be
Godly, from th'Court must get him gone:
Vertue and highest dignity
Do very seldom meet in one.
Exemplo alterius qui sapit, ille sapit.
He's wise indeed, that wisdom learns
By what in others he discorns.
Exemplis sanè qui docet, ille docet.
He teacheth best, that teacheth by examples.
Exemplo virtus benè discitur, at{que} docetur.
Vertue is well learnt and taught by examples.
Exitus acta probat: careat successibus opto,
Quisquis ab eventu facta notanda putat.
The End does crown the work, 'tis true:
But good success to such I grudge,
As by th'events of matters doe
The actions goodness wholly judge.
Exerce studium, quamvis perceperis artem.
Though in an Art you have gain'd skill,
Practise you should and study still.
Eximia est virtus praestare silentia rebus,
At contra gravis est culpa tacenda loqui.
Silence is good, and on the contrary
'Tis bad to utter what conceal'd should be.
Exiguum colito, laudato ingentia rura.
A larger Farm, praise if you will,
But choose a little one to till.
Exiguum munus cùm dat tibi pauper amicus,
Accipito placidè. —
Accept kindly of thy poor Friends gift, though it be but small.
Exigua est tribuenda fides, qui multa loquuntur.
Little credit is to be given to their words that are full of Talk.
Exilis domus est, ubi non & multa supersunt,
Et dominum fallunt.—
That House is meanly furnish'd where there are
Not many things unknown of, and to spare.
Expletur lachrymis egeritur{que} dolor.
Tears give a vent to grief,
And thereby yield relief.
Expedit extremae meditari tempora vitae.
It is good to meditate on our latter End.
Explorant adversa viros; perque aspera duro
Nititur ad laudem virtus interrita clivo.
Adversity tryes men; Vertue seeks praise
Undauntedly through steep and rugged wayes.
Extra fortunam est quicquid donatur amicis.
What is given to our Friends is safe, and out of Fortunes reach.
Explicuit vino contractae seria frontis.
He did with Wine himself though troubled cheer,
And smooth'd the wrinkles of his brow severe.
Exultat levitate puer, gravitate senectus.
A Boy gloryes in his Levity, and an Old Man in his Gravity.
Exoepto quod non simul esses, caetera laetus.
I am very well and cheerfull, save that I want your company.
Expende Annibalem, quot libras in duce summo
Invenies? —
Though Hannibal did once bear such a sway,
How few pounds now will's Bones & Ashes weigh?
Exemplo quodcunque malo committitur, ipsi
Displicet authori. —
The crime in evil Presidents,
The very Author much torments.
Excussus propriis aliena negotia curo.
Having no business of my own, I doe
My self in other mens affairs bestow.

div.p: That you finde so many of the Sentences rendred in English Verse, is not because I was thereto encouraged by any great Poetical vein, but because some of them otherwise rendred would have appeared slat. It was beside my first intention, and hence you will finde little thereof towards the beginning. I have not kept my self to Verses of one sort or length; for neither are they so in the Latin, nor have the Sentences any connexion or dependency one upon another. To some few of those out of Horace and Juvenal, I have given the rendring of the Translators of those Authors, especially where I found it best suit with my own Fancy and Design. That I have inserted out of Authors many Sentences of more than one or two Verses apiece, and such also as are not Hexameters nor Pentameters; was because I apprehended that other uses may possibly be made of this Book by some, than barely for capping: And yet why Youth may not, if the Teacher please, profitably cap out of these also, I know not, except that it hath been customary to do otherwise. If any differ in opinion from me herein, they are at their liberty; and I suppose here are enough single and compleat Verses of the Heroic and Elegiac sort, competently to serve their purpose.

I have nothing more to advertise the Reader, but concerning the Faults that have escaped the Press, wherein the Printer doth the more confidently hope for a favourable Candour, because they are but few,
and the most of those too but Literal; however it was thought meet they should be here subjoyned.
